title: Position Sensorless Control of SRMs Based on Neural Network Nonlinear Modeling Using Improved Coyote Optimization Algorithm
authors: Yifei Yang, Xiaodong Sun, Yifang Wen, Renzhong Wang, Nuonuo Wang
abstract: This paper presents a sensorless control method of switched reluctance motor (SRM) based on flux linkage nonlinear modeling. This method combines radial basis function neural network ( ) with improved coyote optimization algorithm (ICOA) to obtain accurate rotor position information. The RBFNN has fast convergence speed and strong approximation ability. The ICOA can dynamically adjust the parameters and structure of RBFNN, and reduce modeling errors by adaptive adjustment of the number of hidden layer nodes. In addition, the rotation speed of the rotor at any position is estimated to realize the accurate commutation of the motor and ensure the stable operation of the whole closed-loop system. Finally, the effectiveness of the RBFNN based on the ICOA is verified through the six-phase 12/10SRM experimental platform.

title: Adaptive Shared Cascade Navigation Control of Magnetic Microrobots in Unstructured Dynamic Environments_supp6-3658831.pdf
authors: Huaping Wang
abstract: Precise motion control of magnetic microrobots in complex and dynamic environments remains a critical challenge for enabling key applications such as targeted therapy and micromanipulation. Purely manual teleoperation is prone to operator fatigue and error, while fully autonomous systems often lack the robustness and adaptability to handle. Here, we propose a human–machine shared cascade control method for magnetically driven microrobots, which effectively integrates human cognitive intelligence with machine autonomy for collision-free navigation in dynamic environments. The outer-loop hybrid shared control unit smoothly modulates control authority in response to real-time collision risk, dynamically integrating the operator instructions and the autonomous navigation system output guided by the enhanced artificial potential field method to formulate the guidance law. For the inner-loop motion tracking, a data-driven adaptive orientation controller is designed, which integrates a nonlinear feedforward compensator leveraging a Gaussian process regression (GPR) model with a linear feedback controller whose parameters are optimized using the virtual reference feedback tuning (VRFT) method, ensuring fast and precise tracking of the desired motion. The effectiveness of the proposed method was validated through both simulation and physical experiments. In human-subject studies conducted on a physical magnetic actuation platform featuring both static and dynamic obstacle scenarios, quantitative results demonstrate that the shared control strategy significantly outperforms both purely manual and fully autonomous modes across all key metrics, including success rate, task completion time, stability, and safety (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$p \lt 0.001$</tex-math> </inline-formula>). Furthermore, successful navigation within a complex gastric model demonstrates the potential of the shared control system for practical application in unstructured environments.

title: An Empirical Exploration Of Collaborative Performance In Engineering Learning Contexts_supp1-3663552.pdf
authors: Oscar Revelo Sanchez
abstract: This study presents an empirical analysis of collaborative performance assessment in engineering learning scenarios. A validated instrument—derived from a previously developed questionnaire measuring seven operational dimensions of collaboration—was applied to evaluate group performance. The study involved 251 students from various engineering courses, organized into experimental groups based on personality traits and a control group formed according to student preference. Findings reveal that personality-based group formation influences collaborative performance, with outcomes varying by group configuration. Homogeneous and mixed groups emphasizing emotional stability (Neuroticism – N) demonstrated higher levels of leadership and collaboration, while heterogeneous groups underperformed compared to the control group. Across all formations, conflict management consistently emerged as the most challenging process, underscoring the importance of targeted strategies for managing interpersonal tensions in team-based learning. From a methodological standpoint, the assessment instrument exhibited high internal consistency (Cronbach’s α > 0.9), affirming its reliability for evaluating collaborative dynamics in academic contexts. The study concludes that personality-informed group formation can optimize specific collaborative processes, though its effectiveness depends on the combination of personality traits within each team. These findings hold significant implications for the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), particularly in informing the design of educational technologies that enable adaptive group formation and provide real-time feedback in collaborative learning environments.

title: ATTE: An Innovative Ensemble Learning Method With Age-Group-Guided Fine-Tuning for Improving Personalized Blood Pressure Estimation_supp1-3655736.pdf
authors: Jingjing Luo
abstract: Precision medicine requires cuffless blood pressure (BP) estimation technologies to achieve high accuracy levels suitable for healthcare monitoring. Recent advances, notably in personalized BP estimation methods utilizing transfer learning, have partially met these requirements. However, traditional personalized fine-tuning pipelines often ignore key physiological factors across age groups, thus limiting their effectiveness. This study identifies an important fine-tuning principle: target subjects benefit most when fine-tuned using a source model pretrained on an age-matched group. We introduce a novel two-level ensemble learning method, ATTE, which integrates multiple BP models for cuffless BP estimation based on pulse waves. It first performs feature-level ensemble learning (FEL) to combine age-group-specific fine-tuned models and enrich representations, then applies an optimized Bayesian model averaging (BMA) method that adaptively weights model outputs to boost accuracy and reduce model-selection uncertainty. Using only 50 transfer samples, ATTE improved systolic and diastolic BP estimation accuracy by 6.55% and 5.58% on a public dataset, compared to the traditional fine-tuning paradigm. It also achieved improvements of 5.10% and 8.30% on a self-collected dataset, which has been preliminarily validated in an elderly care scenario. Ablation and interpretability analyses validated the age-matched fine-tuning principle, the effectiveness of ATTE, and its model-agnostic generalizability. This work represents a pioneering step in optimizing personalized BP estimation and underscores its significant potential for real-world healthcare applications.

title: A Consumption-Generation Driven Deep Embedding Framework for Next Activity Prediction
authors: Chao Zheng, Jian Wang, Maodong Li, Bing Li, Wei Song
abstract: Next activity prediction, a critical subtask of Predictive Process Monitoring (PPM), aims to forecast the upcoming activity of an ongoing process instance based on event logs generated by process-aware information systems, thereby enabling businesses to proactively mitigate potential risks. While recent deep sequence models have shown strong predictive capabilities, they often fail to explicitly capture the intrinsic dependencies that govern the conditions and impacts of event occurrences in business processes. To address this limitation, we propose a novel Place-Transition Embedding (PTE) framework that captures these dependencies through Petri-net–inspired token consumption and generation semantics. PTE employs a deep embedding network to simulate the evolution of markings, i.e., how each observed event drives token dynamics over places over time under our resource interpretation. In addition, we introduce a temporal scoring mechanism that ranks candidate activities by jointly considering resource feasibility and temporal urgency, improving both interpretability and predictive accuracy. Extensive experiments on six real-world datasets show that PTE achieves state-of-the-art performance for next-activity prediction. Moreover, PTE generalizes robustly under sparse training conditions, highlighting its practical applicability in real-world scenarios with limited business data.

title: A Climate-Aware Modeling Framework for Reliable IoT Connectivity: Environmental Effects on LoRaWAN Signal-to-Noise Ratio
authors: Spyros Lavdas, Nikolaos Bakas, Wassim El Hajj, Zinon Zinonos
abstract: The performance of large-scale Long-Range Wide Area Network (LoRaWAN) deployments is typically evaluated using conventional link metrics such as distance, transmit power, and spreading factor. However, the role of environmental variables has remained largely unexplored, despite their potential to significantly alter signal quality. In this paper, we introduce a climate-aware modeling framework that quantifies and predicts how temperature and humidity affect the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) across heterogeneous IoT deployment scenarios. Using a city-scale dataset from more than 30,000 sensors, the proposed framework integrates statistical characterization (PDF/CDF and outage modeling) with a predictive learning component based on gradient-boosted decision trees, forming a unified modeling pipeline that links environmental variability, SNR distributional behavior, and predictive response. The framework is evaluated across three representative topologies—Free, Covered, and Underground—providing a structured understanding of environment-conditioned reliability in LoRaWAN networks. Our results show that temperature and humidity induce measurable shifts in SNR distributions, and that incorporating them into the predictive model yields consistent accuracy gains, improving test-set performance by up to Δr2 = 0.445 over signal-only baselines (depending on topology and SF). Beyond prediction accuracy, the model’s outputs can be directly integrated into Adaptive Data Rate (ADR) management and network planning, demonstrating its applicability for system-level IoT optimization. These findings demonstrate that climate-aware modeling is not only relevant but essential for reliable Internet of Things (IoT) connectivity, offering new directions for adaptive LoRaWAN network planning and deployment in diverse urban environments.

title: Joint Jamming and Transmission Rate Optimization for Multi-jammer Assisted UAV Covert Communications with Imperfect CSI
authors: Zhijun Han, Yiqing Zhou, Ningzhe Shi, Jingya Yang, Ling Liu, Jinglin Shi, Shuwu Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Information security and privacy are critical for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) based low-altitude networks. To enhance the security of the UAV transmitter, this paper inves tigates the jammer-assisted UAV covert communication systems with imperfect CSI, where part of friendly jammers is selected to send artificial noise (AN) to confuse the warden. Then, the UAV transmitter can hide the transmitted signals into “noise”, decreasing warden's detection probability for the transmission behavior. It is important to jointly optimize the jammer selection and jamming power, as AN sent by friendly jammers will interfere with the warden and receiver, simultaneously. However, existing channel-aware schemes work with a perfect channel state information (CSI) of the transmitter-to-receiver (i.e., covert link) and jammer-to-receiver links, which is impractical in low-altitude networks. Therefore, this paper concerns the imperfect CSI of the covert link and the channel distribution information (CDI) of the UAV transmitter-to-warden link and jamming links from the jammers to the warden and receiver. First, given the imperfect CSI, the warden's average detection error probability (WADEP) is analyzed. Then, given that WADEP is higher than the covert ness constraint, the covert throughput is analytically derived and maximized by jointly optimizing the jammer selection, jamming power, and transmission rate (J-JamSPR-ImCSI). Since the optimization problem is NP-hard, a two-step Jensen's inequality based algorithm is proposed to provide a heuristic solution (2 Step-JIHA). The main idea is to first jointly optimize jammer selection and jamming power with the covertness constraint to minimize the average received AN power at the receiver (which negatively impacts the covert throughput), then a bisection method can be employed to obtain the optimal transmission rate maximizing the covert throughput. Numerical results show that the proposed 2-Step-JIHA can provide a near optimal covert throughput with a lower complexity. Moreover, when the CSI is imperfect, compared to the existing channel-aware scheme, the proposed J-JamSPR-ImCSI with 2-Step-JIHA can improve the covert throughput by 54.26%, when the covertness constraint is 0.9.

title: Vision Transformer-Based Swin Transformer for Automated Diabetic Retinopathy Severity Detection and Classification
authors: Praveena Mallampalli, Mahaveerakannan R
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Diabetes-related retinopathy (DR) can cause permanent vision loss if not detected early. CNNs are widely used to classify DR however, they can't detect global spatial linkages and small progression patterns needed to assess disease severity accurately. To address the major CNN issues, the proposed research creates STBDR-Net (Swin Transformer-Based Diabetic Retinopathy Network) to solve these problems. Swin Transformer hierarchical attention methods are used in this design. A 224x224 Gaussian-filtered EyePACS dataset is used to train the model; this strategy clarifies the lesion and ensures the transformer framework receives input with the exact resolution. There are five DR severity levels: nil, mild, moderate, severe, and proliferative. Complex preprocessing methods, including contrast normalization and attention-based filtering, ensure accurate classification for all five DR severity levels in STBDR-Net. STBDR-Net outperforms CNNs and baseline transformer models in terms of accuracy, F1-score, and weighted metrics. This is true when comparing the two methods. Mild and moderate DR might confuse automated systems. The model distinguishes mild and moderate DR well. STBDR-Net is a trustworthy and useful real-world DR screening tool. Visual transformer-based learning samplings aid scalable, accurate clinical decision-making.

title: Design and Implementation of a Trust-Based Peer-to-Peer Lending Platform for Hyperlocal Academic Communities
authors: Gurusigaamani Ayyanar Muthulingam, Dinesh Karthik M, Aathi Seshan P, Ganesh Aditya R S, Vijaya Nivas M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: The growth of the sharing economy has become a prime area for resource optimization, but a gap exists for safe, trustworthy systems at the hyperlocal level, such as university campuses. The present paper outlines the design and development of CampusLend, a full-stack web application built to enable safe peer-to-peer (P2P) lending and swapping of tangible items. The ultimate mission is to establish a closed-loop, sustainable system that optimizes resource use and reduces wastage for the consumer on a university-wide scale. The system is built on a hybrid cloud infrastructure, merging a MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React, Node.js) for the primary application logic and a Firebase backend-as-a-service (BaaS) for strong authentication, file storage, and in-real-time database operations. One significant achievement of this work is the integration of a dynamic Trust Scoring Algorithm that gives a measurable indicator of the user trustworthiness through a history of transactions and completeness of the profile, consequently reducing associated P2P exchange risks. It has a real-time alert system, implemented using Socket.IO, that ensures immediate communication for item requests, acceptances, and updates on status between borrowers and lenders. The React-based web application also has a clean, responsive, and easy-to-use item listing, browsing, and profile interface, making the whole experience smooth and seamless. The paper outlines the system design, trust model, real-time communication protocol, and general implementation, illustrating a scalable and a safe solution for ensuring a sharing and collaborative ecosystem that is sustainable and workable within a school setting.

title: Ranking-Aware Predictor-Assisted Automatic Architecture Design for Biomedical Image Segmentation
authors: Nan Li, Meirui He, Aohan Mei, Zhicheng Wu, Tian Zhang, Ruwang Jiao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM)
abstract: Biomedical image segmentation plays a critical role in clinical applications such as disease diagnosis and surgical planning. While deep learning, especially U-Net and its variants, have achieved impressive performance in this domain, their success heavily relies on manual architectural design, which limits scalability and generalizability. Neural architecture search (NAS) offers a promising solution by automating model design, but existing NAS-based methods still suffer from high computational costs and limited architectural diversity. In this work, we propose a novel NAS framework, termed ranking-aware predictorassisted architecture design (RPA2D), for efficient and accurate biomedical image segmentation. RPA2D introduces a lightweight and expressive search space comprising diverse convolution and pooling operations tailored for medical images. Furthermore, we design a contrastive learning-based ranking-aware performance predictor that enables accurate architecture ranking under limited supervision. Extensive experiments on public biomedical datasets demonstrate that RPA2D consistently outperforms both handcrafted and NAS-based baselines in segmentation accuracy while significantly reducing search overhead.

title: AI-Generated Content and Its Influence on Consumer Trust and Purchase Behaviour: Evidence from Bangladesh’s E-Commerce Industry
authors: Tahsina Khan, Md Mehedi Hasan Emon
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: This study was conducted to explore how different features of AI-generated content such as INF, PER, AUT, and VRI affect TRU and their intention to buy from e-commerce platforms in Bangladesh. Based on the Stimulus-Organism-Response (S-O-R) model and the AI acceptance framework, a quantitative method was used, collecting survey data from 143 online shoppers through convenience sampling. The data were analyzed using SmartPLS with SEM to examine the hypothesized relationships. The results showed that all the content attributes had significant and positive effects on TRU, which itself had a positive impact on CPI. Among these attributes, VRI was found to be the most influential, highlighting the value of attractive and high-quality visuals in building trust and encouraging purchases. Practically, the findings suggest that e-commerce businesses should focus on improving AI-driven content strategies that emphasize INF, PER, AUT, and appealing visuals, especially in fast-growing markets like Bangladesh. From a social perspective, the study reflects how consumers are increasingly accepting AI technologies, leading to more interactive and trustworthy online shopping experiences. Theoretically, this research contributes by applying AI content features within the S-O-R framework in a developing country context, offering new insights into how AI shapes consumer decisions. However, limitations such as the use of convenience sampling and a cross-sectional design are acknowledged, and future studies are recommended to use longitudinal approaches and more representative samples for better generalizability.

title: LLM-Guided Multimodal Scene Captioning via Prompt-Based Fusion of Visual and Auditory Descriptions
authors: Md. Asraful Islam Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Understanding complex scenes in real world environments often demands more than visual analysis alone it requires the integration of both visual and auditory cues. This study investigates whether prompt-based fusion using large language models (LLMs) can effectively combine modality specific outputs for zero-shot scene captioning. We propose a modular framework that leverages BLIP-2 for visual captioning, Whisper for audio transcription, and FLAN-T5 for prompt-driven fusion. To simulate multimodal caption pairs, we augment the COCO image caption dataset with text-to-speech (TTS) generated audio and incorporate filtered real-world audio-image samples. Unlike prior approaches requiring joint training or architectural modification, our pipeline operates entirely in zero-shot mode with no model retraining. Evaluation using BLEU, ROUGE-L, and cosine-based semantic similarity reveals that our fusion strategy, despite its simplicity, achieves semantically coherent captions across modalities. This work demonstrates the feasibility of LLM-guided fusion for assistive AI and offers a reproducible, low-resource solution for applications such as smart narration, AR/VR accessibility, and navigation aids for visually impaired users.

title: FusionNet+: A Multi-Modal Deep Ensemble Architecture for Predicting Natural Disaster Severity and Economic Loss
authors: Saiful Islam, Ridwan Ahmed Arman, Maruf Hossain, Md Khairul Kabir Simul, Aman Ullah, Sultana Akter
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Human lives, infrastructure, and economic prosperity are among the major risks that natural catastrophes pose to society, especially in the vulnerable regions where there is little to no early-warning system. To fulfill the demand for precise and explainable forecasting, this paper proposes an ensemble learning framework, called FusionNet+, that can combine various data to predict the intensity and the economic burden of a natural disaster. To model the architecture, the architecture can be arranged into three hierarchical layers, the Spatiotemporal Weather Data Response (STWDR) module, which characterizes climatic characteristics in convolutional and recurrent layers; Multi-Information Decision Prediction (MIDP) module, which integrates social and infrastructural indicators with contextual relevance; and Multi-modal Ensemble (MME) layer of combining outputs with optimum weighted fusion. The combination of these elements allows processing heterogeneous inputs such as weather data, disaster records and real-time social signals end-to-end. FusionNet+ has been tested on selected dataset based on EM-DAT and additional sources, and proved to be a better model in all measurement of predicting results. The model had an R 2 score of 0.914, a mean absolute error (MAE) decrease of 22 percent, and 92.6 percent of classification accuracy, which significantly outperforms traditional machine learning models (Linear Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost) and baseline deep learning architectures (LSTM, CNN, Transformer). Moreover, explainable AI methods (SHAP and LIME) were used to gain transparency, which provides some piece of information regarding the role of each input modality as opposed to others.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-based Mobile Ad Hoc Network for Secure and Dynamic Routing through Cryptographic Assurance
authors: M. Sasikala, S. Meera, A. Selva Priya, R. Durai Vasanth, B. Senthilkumaran, J. Viji Gripsy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: In Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs), route discovery and maintenance are costly in terms of network overhead, which degrades performance, shortens network lifespan, and results in network partitioning. The extremely dynamic nature of node movement and topological changes requires the deployment of clever, adaptive routing schemes that can deliver data packets to their destinations efficiently. In such scenarios, route paths are often changed due to changes in link connectivity, resulting in reliability and stability of data transfer as a critical problem. This research deals with these problems by utilizing DRL-MANET — a Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Routing protocol that combines route stability metrics and security-aware decision-making. DRL-MANET applies deep Q-learning to dynamically acquire the best routing routes according to the current network state, residual energy level, trust values, and link quality, and integrates anomaly detection to prevent malicious nodes. The main goal of this paper is to design and compare a DRL-based routing approach to improve route stability, packet delivery ratio, delay reduction, and security in MANET networks. The suggested framework is able to prove its worth in reaching effective, secure, and adaptive routing, providing a smooth solution for large and dynamic MANET deployments.

title: Early Detection of Myocardial Infarction using Advanced AI Techniques
authors: Raashi Bafna, Rakhi Chengte, Rachana R Aithal, Ravilla Jagadeesh, Kamatchi Priya L
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Myocardial infarction (MI), commonly known as a heart attack, continues to be a leading cause of mortality worldwide, particularly affecting older adults and individuals with diabetes. This study introduces an AI-driven framework for early MI risk prediction by integrating clinical, lifestyle, and historical medical data. The proposed system employs multiple machine learning (ML) models—including Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost—enhanced through advanced feature selection methods such as Minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance (mRMR) and L1 regularization. Among all models and feature selection techniques evaluated, Random Forest achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 76.65%, precision of 82.17%, and F1-score of 74.46%. Gradient boosting techniques also demonstrated strong performance while offering interpretable insights. The results highlight the effectiveness of combining AI methodologies with domain expertise to deliver transparent, personalized, and proactive solutions for early MI detection.

title: Lip-Sync Analyzer for Deepfake Detection and Peeking Behind the Black Box with Explainable AI
authors: Sadman Sakib, S. M. Rafizul Haque, Atanu Shome
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The swift evolution of deepfake technology presents significant threats to the credibility and trustworthiness of digital media. This work presents a deepfake detection framework that combines spatial and audio-visual features, with a specific focus on lip-sync forgeries. We evaluate multiple state-of-the-art CNN architectures—DenseNet-121, EfficientNet-B0, InceptionV3, ResNet-50, and XceptionNet—alongside a Vision Transformer (ViT-B/32). Experiments on the AVLips dataset (3,396 real and 4,206 fake videos) show that ViT-B/32 achieves superior performance, with 96% F1-score, and 99% AUC. Audio-visual fusion consistently outperforms visual-only models, highlighting the strength of multimodal analysis. To enhance transparency, LIME-based explainable AI visualizations are employed to interpret model predictions. Unlike previous works that primarily rely on unimodal cues, our approach uniquely integrates audio waveforms with visual frames to expose subtle inconsistencies in lip synchronization. Given the potential misuse of deepfakes in misinformation, fraud, and political manipulation, this study emphasizes the urgent need for robust and interpretable detection methods. Our findings confirm the effectiveness of transformer-based models with XAI for dependable deepfake detection, with future work focusing on temporal modeling and scalability.

title: Early Detection of Cardiovascular Diseases Using Self-Supervised Learning on Echocardiography Images
authors: Steve Joshua T, Sophia S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are a constant problem to the health of our world and this aspect highlights that there is a dire need to find ways that will facilitate early and accurate diagnoses. The paper introduces a deep learning methodology that concentrates on categorizing the echocardiographic pictures into four diagnosis groups: Angina Pectoris, Coronary Artery Disease, Left Ventricular Hypertrophy and Cardiovascular Disease. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) can be used to derive important spatial and structural features of the heart ultrasound scan. To overcome weaknesses associated with small data reduction in annotation, the system inserts self-supervised learning to enhance efficiency and generalizing learning. The additional expression of features using texture-based descriptors, e.g., the Gray-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) helps describe textural information contained within details. The specified integrated framework is created to guide clinicians in reaching immediate and informed decisions with the scope of stipulating early-stage identification and striving to influence positive outcomes of cardiac care.

authors: Mahendra Kumar Das, Vimal Kumar Singh Yadav, Rajesh Kumar Lal
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: In this work, we present a novel quantum well design based on an asymmetric MoS2/Zn1-xMgxO heterostructure for terahertz (THz) detection around 3.2 THz. At this frequency, the intersubband transitions are supported by a well width of about 156 Å, which is equivalent to a 24-layer MoS2 quantum well. The MoS2/Zn1-xMgxO material system exhibits type-II band alignment, which promotes charge separation, while the structural asymmetry breaks wave function parity and enables transverse electric (TE) polarized intersubband transitions. These transitions are generally forbidden in symmetric quantum wells due to optical selection rules. The optical properties and energy levels are computed using the Finite Difference Method (FDM) and Transfer Matrix Method (TMM) for numerical and analytical verification. The proposed 156 Ǻ MoS2 well structure shows a peak responsivity of 2.04 A/W and a specific detectivity of at 77 K. The findings confirm that the proposed asymmetric structure and material system synergistically enhance optical absorption and confinement THz frequency regime.The originality of this work lies in the detector’s sensitivity to sub-nanometer changes in well width, enabling wavelength-selective operation. This tunability offers a strong potential for integration into terahertz Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) systems. The results support the application of 2D material-based Asymmetric Quantum Well (AQW) structures in narrowband THz photodetectors for upcoming communication and sensing technologies.

title: IoT-Based Continuous Mental Health Monitoring System for Schizophrenia Patients
authors: Jananee J, F. Emerson Solomon
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Schizophrenia is a persistent mental illness that demands constant attention to detect early relapse and offer good management. Conventional episodic tests are unable to reflect changes in behavior in the moment-to-moment situation. In response to this, a continuous mental health monitoring system based on the use of IoT is offered, which includes multimodal sensors to monitor HRV, electrodermal activity, sleep patterns, physical activity, and speech behavior. The personalized anomaly detection is implemented using a Temporal Convolutional Autoencoder (TCAE), which retrieves a compressed behavioral state vector from time-series sensor data. The system provided an anomaly detection accuracy of 94.2%, precision of 91.7%, and recall of 93.5%, a success rate of 99.2 % of alert deliveries, and average latency of less than 1.2 seconds. The proposed model outperformed settlement systems in terms of real-time responsiveness, privacy encryption, and user satisfaction compared to earlier schemes. In conclusion, the system will facilitate a scalable and smart treatment system for schizophrenia and huge mental health enhancement to track health issues and provide real-time alerts with specific feedback systems.

title: Exploring the Therapeutic Potential of Aloe vera extracted compounds Against NSCLC: A Molecular Docking and Dynamic Simulation Study
authors: Md. Mobinul Hoque, Tamanna E Jannati, Tawsif Al Arian, Md Sarowre Hossen, Md. Shamim, Md Habibur Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Lung cancer can manifest in four basic histological forms: large cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, small cell carcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma. Approximately 85% are responsible for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) from all cases. The 5-year survival rate is only 12–16%, despite major advances in medicinal drugs, surgical procedures, and diagnostic tests. Therefore, we were inspired to perform a comprehensive study to suggest more potential drug candidates for lung cancer. In our study, we employed various computational methods, like PASS prediction, drug-likeness properties prediction, molecular docking, ADMET properties analysis, molecular dynamic simulations, and post simulation analysis. From the analysis of PASS, ADMET, and Lipinski’s rule of five, the molecules M3 and M4 have strong drug properties for cancer therapy. A better binding affinity (-9.3 kcal/mol) was found for M1, M3, and M4. A more stable energy gap was found than that of the standard. The molecular dynamic result is better than the standard. A more favorable binding free energy is found in the ligands M3 (Aloin A) and M4 (Aloin B). From our findings, we may suggest that the molecules M3 (Aloin A) and M4 (Aloin B) have more potency than the control Gefitinib (D1) as a lung cancer inhibitor. These two compounds should be further validated by in vitro and in vivo studies.

title: Electro-Thermal Simulation and Analysis of a Semiconductor Device Using Bipolar Junction Transistor
authors: Rama Rao Chekuri, Harshith Sai M, Lathika M, Odnala Bhargavi, Subramanyam Raju P, Gorla Sai Venkat Narayana
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Thermal analysis plays a critical role in the design and reliability of semiconductor devices. This paper presents an electro-thermal simulation of a semiconductor chip incorporating a bipolar junction transistor (BJT) using COMSOL Multiphysics. The simulation models heat generation via Joule heating and analyzes temperature distribution and heat dissipation across copper traces and device terminals. The study demonstrates the importance of thermal conduction paths and material selection in minimizing hotspots and ensuring operational safety. The results validate the effectiveness of passive thermal management strategies and highlight the applicability of multiphysics simulation tools in semiconductor device design.

title: Evaluating the Efficacy of Explainable Machine Learning Algorithms for the Detection and Classification of Network Intrusions
authors: Alabhia Talukder, Md. Baker, Atiqur Rahman, Mohammad Ashrafuzzaman Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: With the increasing complexity and frequency of cyberattacks, conventional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are often inadequate in identifying novel threats such as Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS), Port Scanning, and Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs). This research presents a hybrid Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) that integrates supervised and unsupervised machine learning models with Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques to enhance threat detection and transparency. Using the UNSW-NB15 dataset, we evaluate classifiers including Random Forest, LightGBM, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Autoencoders, and Deep Neural Networks. A voting-based ensemble strategy is implemented to improve robustness and generalization across diverse attack types. The ensemble model achieves a peak accuracy of 89%, with notable performance in detecting low-frequency and stealthy threats. To promote model interpretability, LIME and SHAP are applied for post hoc explanation, enabling clear visualization of feature contributions at both local and global levels. A web-based interface is also developed, offering real-time monitoring, alert generation, and analytics for security analysts. This study demonstrates that combining high-performing machine learning models with XAI techniques can significantly improve the adaptability, interpretability, and operational effectiveness of modern IDS frameworks.

title: Predictive Modeling of Credit Risk in Banking Systems Using a Hybrid SVM–Random Forest Approach
authors: U. Naresh Kumar, T. Gangadharam, K S S Narayana, Jafersadhiq A, M. Sucharitha, Abhishek Tripathi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: In financial systems, credit risk refers to the possibility that a debtor would fail to fulfill their agreed-upon commitments. Credit issuance is a core function of modern banks and involves assessing various criteria. However, repayment issues offer considerable risks to banks, hence comprehensive risk management is required. Because of the close relationship between credit risk and prospective investment returns, institutions that practice good risk control undertake comprehensive evaluations. In order to predict credit risk using various datasets, this research investigates the function of data preparation. An approach to enhance prediction performance is suggested, which involves combining a stacked classifier method with a filter-based feature selection methodology. This method combines the predictions of two different models, RF and SVM, and then uses a Bayesian average to combine the two. Results from a comparison of RF, SVM, and their ensemble reveal that the suggested SVM-RF model outperforms the others. Banks will be able to better identify high-risk borrowers and increase financial stability thanks to the results, which show that ensemble learning and feature selection, can greatly improve credit risk assessment with a prediction rate of 94.53%.

title: Enhancing Agri – Food Supply Chain Efficiency Through Cloud Computing Solutions
authors: Suthi G, Balakrishnan D, Sivaranjani R S, Deebika R, Abhinaya B, Shree Priyanka V L
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Agri-food supply chains frequently struggle with high functional costs, slow decision-making and is the backbone of layer-based AI models like LSTM and Random Forest, which limit scalability and effectiveness. To address these challenges, this paper introduces Adaptive Federated Learning-Based Force Chain Optimization (AFL-SCO), an AI-driven frame designed to enhance real-time decision-making while reducing pall reliance. AFL-SCO incorporates Federated Learning, Edge AI and Blockchain, allowing farms and estates to train AI models locally on Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) and XGBoost, transmitting only essential model updates to the spoils. A tone-optimizing AI model selection medium ensures dynamic switching between Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN), Motor AI and XGBoost, optimizing prediction accuracy. Blockchain-grounded smart contracts enable secure, automated supplier deals, while AI-powered adaptive logistics proactively acclimate to transportation dislocations, request oscillations and rainfall conditions. Performance evaluation reveals substantial advancements, including an increase in AI delicacy from 78-85 to 88-92, a 50-60 reduction in spoilage costs, decision potentially dropping from 5-10 seconds to just 1-2 seconds and a 3x improvement in scalability. These advancements make AFL-SCO a cost-effective, scalable and high-performance AI-driven result for remodeling agri-food supply chains.

title: Explainable Fake News Detection: A Comparative Framework Using Classical, Deep, and Transformer Models
authors: Nusrat Kaniz Khan, Nusrat Sharmin
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The deliberate spread of fake information on social media endangers public trust. To combat this, we conduct a comprehensive fake news detection pipeline that incorporates both classical and state-of-the-art techniques. Our contributions include: integrating transformer-based models (e.g. BERT, RoBERTa) to capture deep contextual semantics; applying text data augmentation (back-translation, synonym replacement) to expand and balance training data; evaluating across multiple benchmarks (LIAR, ISOT, FakeNewsNet) for robustness; and employing advanced explainability (LIME, SHAP and attention visualization) to interpret model predictions. Experimental results show that transformer models and augmentation significantly improve detection rates and explainability tools highlight the key words influencing the predictions. These enhancements make the fake news classifier more accurate, reliable, and transparent.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Early Warning System for Epidemic and Pandemic Outbreaks with Explainable AI
authors: Rahik Ahmed, Samma-E-Aunjum Aurnima, Md. Appel Mahmud Pranto, Rafia Tamanna, A. B. M. Kabir Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: This paper describes a machine learning–driven early warning system for predicting hospitalizations and outbreak trends of diseases like COVID-19, Influenza, and RSV. Using a merged CDC dataset containing 257,388 records, the system leverages advanced feature engineering and a novel outbreak labeling strategy based on disease-specific thresholds. Models including LSTM, Random Forest, LightGBM, and XGBoost were evaluated, achieving 93.6 percent classification accuracy and 97 percent regression accuracy. To enhance interpretability, SHAP-based Explainable AI techniques were integrated, offering transparent insights into feature importance and model decisions. The combination of high accuracy and explainability ensures practical utility in real-time epidemic surveillance and public health readiness.

title: Deepfake Detection in MIS: Leveraging DenseNet and Multi-Scale Information for Enhanced Digital Forensics
authors: Md Anisur Rahman Chowdhury, Khandakar Rabbi Ahmed, Shahriar Alam Robin, Shah Tawkir Nesar, Towfika Salam, Md. Naimul Ahsan, Md Eahia Ansari
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The artificially created media produced with the aid of artificial intelligence (AI), commonly referred to as deepfakes, are posing a serious challenge to the integrity of Management Information Systems (MIS). To achieve this, the paper proposes a new deep learning (DL) model, DGAF-Net (DenseNet + Gabor Attention Fusion Network), to enhance the accuracy of detecting such manipulated content. DGAF-Net incorporates DenseNet121, which is used to extract semantic features with the Gabor filter as a texture feature to generate this information through a Gated Attention Fusion Mechanism (GAFM). The pair of branches in this organization enables the successful detection of both local and global facial image anomalies, particularly in realistic scenarios with compression and noise. When tested on the FaceForensics++ dataset, the model attains a better accuracy of 88.33%, which is better than current baselines, such as Vision Transformer (ViT-B16) and Swin Transformer + CNN fusion models. The findings demonstrate the validity, scalability, efficiency, and generality of DGAF-Net as a solution for real-time MIS digital forensics, as well as a scalable approach to deepfake methods that are becoming increasingly advanced.

title: Design and Development of an IoT-Based Poultry Integrated Aquaponics System: A Sustainable Solution
authors: Md. Obaidur Rahman, Nayeem Ullah, Khawja Imran Masud, Mehedi Hasan Shuvo
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: To meet the growing demands of food and, conversely, due to the crisis of land resources in densely populated countries, aquaponics (i.e., combining aquafarming and hydroponics together) can be an effective solution. In addition, if poultry farming is integrated with that of aquaponics in a multi-layer system, then it can be considered a promising sustainable solution with the context to solve the limited land resources. Additionally, in the era of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) the Internet of Things (IoT) has proven to be a very effective technology for precision agriculture. Currently, very little research has considered the poultry integrated aquaponics system. Even though few studies have been found in the literature addressing the systems individually, they lack in integrating all three systems (i.e., aquaponics, poultry, and plants) together. Moreover, use of IoT for such systems has been practiced rarely. Therefore, in this research, we have designed and developed a poultry integrated multi-layer aquaponics system. The structure of the system includes a bottom layer for fish farming, a middle layer for poultry farming, and an upper layer for plant cultivation. In this system, bi-products of one layer can be used as pesticides and herbicides at the other layers. Finally, the experimental results have shown satisfactory and acceptable output suitable for water level maintenance, pH level control, turbidity monitoring, temperature control, humidity measurement, and moisture level monitoring for plants, poultry, and fish farming through the proposed aquaponics system. Following three days of testing with two-hour sampling intervals, the prototype demonstrated the viability of fish, plant, and poultry interaction, pH control, and water recirculation. The study provides a feasible IoT foundation for integrated smart farming, even though long-term stability and nutrient-cycle monitoring still require investigation.

title: Integrate Blockchain and Federated Learning Approaches to Secure Multi-Cloud Data Exchange: An AI-Powered Trust Management System
authors: Satheesh Prabhu Gurusamy, Shubhanshu Sharma, Anil Kumar V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Multi-cloud environments have emerged as one of the leading methods to manage large-scale, distributed and diverse-situated heterogeneous data across different industries (healthcare, finance, smart cities) in the age of digital transformation. On the other hand, this widespread exchange of data across cloud boundaries, also known as Data Mesh has unleashed large security and trust issues. Federated Learning (FL) is a decentralized machine learning paradigm that incorporates the privacy-preserving technique, allowing multiple parties to train AI models cooperatively without having to reveal the raw data. While FL offers several advantages due to decentralized training, it still faces some challenges like poisoning attacks, trust management and lack of accountability across clouds. Thus, this research provides an integrated framework combining Federated Learning and Blockchain technology for the first time rendering a stable, transparent, and AI infested trust management system among multi-cloud data transaction while countervailing all these impediments. The architecture proposes using the immutability and decentralized consensus of Blockchain to validate and record trust scores, model updates, as well as participant behavior in a federated network. Smart contracts are used to enforce fine-grained access control dynamically and incentivize data providers and cloud nodes to behave honestly. To train models across various data silos, we use Federated Learning and deploy an AI-driven trust engine that continuously assesses the credibility of nodes based on behavioral analytics as well as quality and historical performance of contribution. This framework guarantees data sovereignty, integrity and auditability while still preserving user privacy. Extensive simulations and empirical analysis show that the proposed system can effectively defend against adversarial threats (e. g., model poisoning, unauthorized access, data tampering). In addition, the federation system was significantly improved about integrity and performance under heterogeneous data and cloud environments with AI models integrated trust-aware functionality. The framework also enables dynamic trust reconfiguration based on emerging threats or policy changes, thereby ensuring long-term scalability and resilience. This research hence serves as a very strong model towards trustworthy multi-cloud ecosystems, closing the gap between secure AI collaboration and transparent data governance.

title: LineCourier: A Semi-Autonomous Mobile Robot for Indoor Logistics
authors: Md Jubaidul Islam Rimon, Md. Mohiuddin Maruf, Siddhartho Sen, Md. Hafizul Imran
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The demand for efficient indoor logistics has driven interest in autonomous and semi-autonomous mobile robotic systems. These systems are useful for transporting items in structured spaces like offices, hospitals, and academic institutions. This paper presents LineCourier, a semi-autonomous mobile robot built for indoor file delivery. The system combines embedded control, line navigation, obstacle detection, and a web-based interface for task control and monitoring. It uses infrared (IR) sensors to follow a black line and an ultrasonic sensor to detect obstacles in its path. An ESP32 microcontroller manages the robot’s functions. It reads sensor data and controls motion through an L298N motor driver. A MERN stack-based web application provides real-time monitoring. It shows the robot’s current position, route, and delivery status. Users can assign tasks and receive live feedback remotely. The system was tested through 300 delivery runs over five separate trials. Each run was assessed for line tracking, obstacle handling, and task completion. A run was considered failed if the robot left the line, did not complete the task, or needed manual help. The robot achieved an average success rate of 96.67%, showing stable and reliable performance. The architecture is modular, which allows easy expansion and future upgrades. The results prove that LineCourier is a reliable solution for indoor logistics and can support smart office automation and service robotics.

title: Optimized Path Estimation in TSP Using a Hybrid Genetic Algorithm and Ant Colony Optimization
authors: Sugumar R, A. H. Nandhu Kishore, A. Sasireka, G. Vinoly, Somasekhar Srinivas V K, M. Saratha
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: The Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP) is a fundamental algorithmic optimisation challenge aimed at determining the shortest route that visits each city precisely once and returns to the origin. Current methodologies, such Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Ant Colony Optimisation (ACO), yield solutions although frequently encounter difficulties with extensive problem situations. This study presents a hybrid GAACO methodology that integrates the experimental advantages of Genetic Algorithms with the localised optimisation ability of Ant Colony Optimisation, resulting in enhanced accuracy and accelerated convergence speeds. The suggested model was evaluated with a synthetic dataset, resulting in an optimal tour length of 428.5 units, a convergence rate of 98.2%, and a processing time of 12.6 seconds. In comparison to baseline methods like Genetic Algorithms, Ant Colony Optimisation, and Simulated Annealing, the hybrid method consistently produced superior outcomes with enhanced stability, demonstrating its applicability in logistics and route optimisation.

title: An IoT Based Smart Hybrid Firefighting Robot with 360° Visual Intelligence for Industrial Safety Applications
authors: Md Shakib Al Basar, Rashmi Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Industrial facility fires pose severe risks to human life, property, and business continuity. Conventional firefighting strategies often require direct human intervention in hazardous environments, exposing personnel to life-threatening conditions and limiting the efficiency of emergency responses. To address these challenges, this research presents an IoT-enabled hybrid robotic firefighting framework that integrates multi-sensor fire detection, rule-based autonomy, and dual suppression mechanisms for enhanced industrial safety. A sensor fusion scheme combining flame, smoke, temperature, and vision modalities enables reliable fire detection and localization, while finite-state behavioural logic governs autonomous navigation, suppression mode selection and operator override. Dual suppression agents—water and Aqueous Film-Forming Foam (AFFF)—provide adaptability across Class A and Class B fire scenarios. Experimental validation under controlled flame conditions demonstrated detection latencies of 1.1–2.3 s across distances up to 50 cm, suppression coverage of 0.11–0.15 m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and real-time situational monitoring with 200–300 ms video latency. These results confirm the feasibility of low-cost, rule-based robotic firefighting solutions in constrained industrial environments.The originality of this study does not lie in the isolated use of commercially available components, but in their systematic integration into a coherent, application-oriented framework tailored to industrial safety in resource-limited regions. This study advances the field by providing a reproducible platform that balances affordability, operational robustness, and practical deployability, thereby bridging the gap between conceptual research and real-world industrial firefighting applications.

title: Enhancing Question Answering System using Ensemble Learning Approach
authors: Sadia Tarin, Mohammad Shamsul Arefin
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The rapid increase in global data necessitates efficient techniques to extract precise answers from vast textual resources. Question Answering (QA) systems tackle this by interpreting natural language queries and retrieving relevant information. This study explores ensemble strategies for sentence-level answer selection, applying one set of strategies to traditional machine learning models and another to deep learning models. Using subsets of the SQuAD benchmark, classifiers including Logistic Regression, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbors, XGBoost, Bi-Lstm, and CNN were developed and evaluated. Ensemble techniques such as hard voting, soft voting, and stacking were employed. Among them, the stacking ensemble of traditional machine learning models—using a Logistic Regression meta-learner—achieved the highest test accuracy of 84.48%, outperforming both individual and deep learning models. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of ensemble strategies in enhancing QA performance under limited computational resources.

title: Enhanced YOLOv5-Based Framework for Obstacle Detection, Depth Estimation, and Navigation Assistance for the Visually Impaired
authors: V. Saroja, A. Muthukumaravel
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: This work presents a YOLOv5-based system enhanced to provide real-time obstacle identification, depth estimations, and intelligent navigation to visually impaired individuals. The proposed system suggests a monocular depth estimate module, contextual audio input, and a modified YOLOv5 architecture to enable accurate and effective surrounds perception. Unlike previous models, this unified method uses attention-based feature refinement and temporal smoothing techniques to increase detection stability and depth accuracy in dynamic settings. The technology is implemented via a low-power edge gadget allowing deployment on wearables and other portable devices. In a variety of indoor and outdoor locations, results from tests indicate that the better framework greatly increases detection accuracy, real-time responsiveness, and user navigation safety. Combining strong vision algorithms with simple aural coaching, the proposed system empowers the visually impaired with improved spatial awareness and mobility confidence: scalable, reasonably priced, and pragmatic.

title: FSG: A Conditional Generative Adversarial Network for Censoring-Aware Survival Prediction in Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation
authors: Swandip Singha, Kazi Aishikuzzaman, Md Rashidul Islam, Mahjabin Siddika Oyshi, Mahmudul Hasan, Abir Ehsan Evan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: In allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (A-HCT), Survival prediction is crucial for guidance in clinical decisions; however, this task is not without complication due to censored time-to-event data and racial-based variation in the modeling of outcomes. A proposal of FairSurviveGAN (FSG) is introduced in this paper, which is a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network designed to generate censoring-aware and demographically balanced patient profiles for survival analysis. Using a large-scale racially stratified dataset of 28,800 A-HCT patients, FSG exploits high-level interactions between clinical measures, survival durations, and censoring variables, hence allowing model training across the underserved races to be more equitable. By integrating stratified concordance optimization, FSG reduces subgroup performance discrepancies while achieving superior predictive accuracy (96.87%) and ROC-AUC (0.9622), outperforming conventional machine learning and deep learning thresholds. Furthermore, improvements in fairness were confirmed through stratified C-index and Brier scores, while clinical interpretability was ensured using SHAP and permutation-based feature importance. These findings emphasize the potential of fairness-aware generative modeling to enhance survival prediction, lessen racial bias, and advance equitable precision medicine.

title: Real-Time Anomaly Detection in Physiological Signals Using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Intelligent Healthcare Monitoring
authors: Krishna Pandey, Suman Kumari, Rahul Joshi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: This paper presents a DRL (deep reinforcement learning) based framework for real-time anomaly detection of physiological signals to improve intelligent healthcare monitoring. By casting anomaly detection as a sequential decision-making problem, the model learns optimal alert strategies from temporal signal sequences utilising a hybrid DQNpool-LSTM architecture. The system is also responsive to dynamic data streams and reduces false alarms using reward-based policy optimisation and attention learning. Comprehensive simulations on ECG and PPG yield high detection accuracy, fast convergence and noise and signal variability robustness. A real-time monitoring dashboard not only confirms practical deployability. This approach provides a scalable, understandable, and adaptive system for proactive real-time anomaly detection in a practical healthcare environment, with implications for timely clinical evasion and patient safety.

title: IoT-Enabled Mobile Robot for Environmental Monitoring with Multi-Modal Communication
authors: Shahin M. Khan, Mumtahina Tasnim Mahi, Tajreen Ferdoush, Mirza Rasheduzzaman
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: This work presents the design and deployment of a cost-effective IoT-enabled mobile robot for real-time environmental observation. The system integrates temperature, humidity, gas, and motion sensors with an ESP8266 microcontroller to enable cloud-based data transmission. A dual-mode communication framework utilizing both Wi-Fi and RF ensures reliable performance, even in low-connectivity environments. Key features include a laser-guided robotic arm for remote manipulation, a motion-triggered camera for visual monitoring, and solar-assisted power management to support extended field deployments. Experimental results demonstrate consistent sensor data acquisition, a communication latency as low as 10 milliseconds, and an energy consumption of approximately 25.6 watts. Compared to existing solutions, the proposed system offers a compact, multifunctional platform with enhanced communication flexibility and energy efficiency, making it suitable for diverse environmental monitoring and remote operation scenarios.

title: Design and Implementation of an Anthropomorphic Robotic Hand with Key Kinematic Properties of Human Hand_supp1-3663977.pdf
authors: Caihua Xiong
abstract: Designing an anthropomorphic robotic hand with few actuators while replicating the dexterous motion capabilities of the human hand remains a challenging problem. In this work, a kinematic synergy analysis method is proposed to identify joints with high motion independence and to quantify the synergistic motion characteristics of joints with strong motion dependence. Based on these findings, design principles for intra finger and inter-finger coupling–compliance mechanisms are developed, enabling the mechanical embodiment of joint kinematic synergies within and between fingers. Furthermore, a design principle for anthropomorphic robotic hands that reduces actuator count while retaining diverse motion functions is formulated. This principle is embodied in a 12-actuator, 21-joint prototype named SX-Hand, featuring a flexible thumb and an articulated palm. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that SX Hand achieves the maximum score in the Kapandji test, performs all 33 grasp types defined in the comprehensive GRASP taxonomy, and executes dexterous in-hand manipulations. The proposed approach provides an effective conceptual and technical route for reproducing rich motion functions with reduced actuation, offering valuable guidance for the development of efficient anthropomorphic robotic hands and other bionic systems.

title: SL0-Net: Fractal Dimension Guided Adaptive Compressed Sensing via Deep Unfolding with Measurement-Injection Cross Attention
authors: Jie Chen, Linxin Zhao, Zinan Yang, Dian Zhang, Bing Wu
abstract: Deep unfolding networks (DUNs), which integrate the interpretability of traditional optimization solvers with the representation learning capabilities of deep neural networks, have shown remarkable potential in compressed sensing (CS). However, existing DUNs treat all image regions uniformly, ignoring structural variations and limiting reconstruction fidelity. Many also require heavy parameters and iterations, while still over-looking fine-grained features and inter-stage dependencies. To address these challenges, this paper proposes the Smoothed ℓ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> Norm Unfolding Network (SL0-Net), a novel adaptive deep CS framework inspired by the traditional smoothed ℓ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> norm optimization algorithm for sparse signal recovery. Specifically, we introduce the fractal dimension as a quantitative metric to precisely characterize the texture complexity of local regions. This design enables SL0-Net to adaptively allocate a significantly higher number of measurements to structurally intricate regions, while assigning fewer measurements to low-complexity regions. Secondly, to mitigate the issue of feature loss and enhance inter-stage information flow, we further design the SL0-inspired Measurement-Injected Cross-Attention (SMICA) module, which effectively captures inter-dependencies between feature maps from different unfolding stages and also explicitly incorporates physical CS measurements into the attention computation pipeline. This design facilitates robust information interaction between high-level abstract feature representations and low-level measurement signals, thereby substantially improving the reconstruction fidelity of fine-grained image details. Extensive experiments were conducted on widely used benchmark datasets to validate the effectiveness of the proposed network. The results demonstrate that the proposed SL0-Net outperforms existing methods in terms of image reconstruction quality, while maintaining a more favorable trade-off between performance and model complexity.

title: ICN-enabled Internet of Robotic Things Data Routing and Access for Post-disaster Areas
authors: Xiaonan Wang, Xinru You
abstract: The Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT) enables real-time data delivery and surveillance in harsh environments. In such monitoring scenarios, users need simultaneous access to diverse real-time data from multiple providers to perform collaborative, integrated analysis. The Information-Centric Networking (ICN) model satisfies this requirement by allowing consumers to efficiently share data from different providers through a single communication process. Based on this observation, we propose an ICN-enabled IoRT data routing and access framework that leverages ICN to enable rapid, simultaneous access to a variety of data. The framework utilizes inter-robot relationships and robot attributes to establish routing paths consisting of backbone robots, enabling unicast-based simultaneous sharing of various data among consumers. The experimental results demonstrate the framework's effectiveness and superiority.

title: RVH-Cover: A Resultant-Vector and Heap-Based WSN Coverage Optimization Algorithm
authors: Zhixin Qi, Haoze Gu, Zemin Chao, Zejiao Dong, Hongzhi Wang, Abaho G. Gershome
abstract: As the cornerstone of the Internet of Things, the deployment of wireless sensor networks remains a challenging problem, as it is difficult to balance coverage quality and computational efficiency, particularly when dealing with large-scale node deployments. To solve this problem, we propose a coverage optimization algorithm that integrates max-heap-based priority maintenance with resultant vector-driven dispersion metrics. Our approach organizes sensor nodes via a max-heap structure and introduces a novel resultant vector-based metric to evaluate coverage potential; the key optimization parameter α for this metric was calibrated through theoretical derivation based on optimal hexagonal geometry. This method implicitly transforms the Unit Disk Cover (UDC for brief) problem into a Discrete Unit Disk Cover (DUDC for brief), achieving real-time performance and high-quality coverage with reduced redundancy. Experimental results demonstrate that our method reaches the best coverage quality compared to baseline methods while maintaining almost the same computational complexity.

title: ADVersa: Abductive Driving Accident Video Understanding_supp1-3663545.pdf
authors: Jianwu Fang
abstract: Understanding traffic accident scenes is a long-standing research for vision-based safe driving. It seeks to answer why accidents occur, how near-crash scenes develop, and what the key elements of an accident are. This research is challenging due to the scarcity and fragmentation of accident data, as well as the complex accident environments. To study this, we present a framework of Abductive Driving accident Video understanding (ADVersa), which infers a plausible visual and textual explanation for the absent near-crash scenes. ADVersa underscores three groups of tasks: 1) visual past recovery of near-crash scenes, 2) visual prediction of near-crash scenes, and 3) accident cause involved video synthesis. To support the study, we first contribute MM-AU, a novel dataset for Multi-Modal Accident video Understanding. MM-AU contains 11,727 in-the-wild driving accident videos with temporally aligned text descriptions, 2.23 million well-annotated object boxes, and 58,650 pairs of video-based accident cause texts. We then propose an Abductive CLIP model and a Contrastive Graph Video Pre-training (CGVP) model, which exploit relation-aware cross-modal semantic learning to drive spatially abductive and temporally abductive accident video diffusion. Extensive experiments verify the superiority of ADVersa to the state-of-the-art approaches on different tasks, i.e., historical near-crash video frame recovering, crashing video frame prediction, textual accident cause and category reasoning, normal-to-accident video synthesis, and accident video editing. With these efforts, we hope this research can advance the progress on multimodal accident video understanding.

title: Toward Autonomous Driving: Data-Model Integration for Trajectory Reconstruction and Driving Action Extraction
authors: Zhoudong Yan, Peng Hang, Zhen Gao, Zaimin Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: With the development of autonomous driving, understanding the behavior of traffic participants has become increasingly important. Vehicle trajectories contain rich information, however, they are often contaminated with noise in real-world environments. While existing trajectory processing methods may incorporate physical models to some extent, they typically struggle to enforce strict adherence to physical constraints. As a result, the processed trajectories may become distorted, making it difficult to accurately infer the driver’s control actions. In this paper, the vehicle kinematic model is embedded into a learnable neural network. By leveraging backpropagation through the physical model, the network can be trained without the need for explicit labels of driving actions. The design of intermediate network layers ensures that the output trajectories strictly satisfy physical constraints and enables robust inference of the driver’s inputs. Cross-dataset experiments demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms direct computation approaches: errors in acceleration and deceleration estimation are reduced by approximately 84%, while steering action errors are reduced by approximately 43%. Real-world vehicle data further validate the trajectory reconstruction method, achieving a 5% reduction in prediction error when applied to fixed-point trajectory prediction models compared to unprocessed trajectories.

title: HarmonyCache: Scalable In-Network Cache With Read-Write Separation
authors: Jiangyuan Chen, Xiaohua Xu, Wenfei Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: In a key-value storage system, a small amount of hot item will account for most of the traffic. Skewed workloads can lead to load imbalance between servers, and some servers that keep hotspots will become system bottlenecks and impact the performance of the entire system. The recent studies have shown that the load imbalance can be eliminated by placing a small, fast cache node in front of the back-end servers, i.e., in-network cache. And the appearance of programmable switches made it possible to place this node on the switch, the place through which the traffic must pass. While existing in-network cache effectively balances loads between servers in large-scale storage systems, they struggle in write-intensive workloads and lose scalability with increasing client numbers due to imbalanced cache nodes. This paper introduces HarmonyCache, a scalable and high-performance in-network cache system that supports write-back methods. HarmonyCache use cache replication and read-write separation mode, only one node in all the cache is responsible for handling write requests, the other node can only handle read requests. To achieve system scalability and minimize cache coherence overhead, HarmonyCache proposes an adaptive cache replication scheme to decide where the cache should be replicated and how many replications should be made. Additionally, according to the requirements of different cache nodes, we design different types of in-network caches using different switch resources and propose a hybrid cache scheme. Our HarmonyCache prototype and extensive experiments demonstrate substantial improvements in key-value store throughput across various access patterns (read/write intensive), achieving a throughput gain of up to 7.6× over state-of-the-art solutions under skewed write-intensive workloads.

title: Exploring Temporal and Manufacturer-Specific Trends of Automated Vehicle Crashes Using Sequence of Events
authors: Cesar Andriola, Madhav V. Chitturi, David A. Noyce
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The present study uses Crash Sequence Analysis to identify automated vehicles (AV) crash patterns and evaluate the temporal (2014 to 2023) and manufacturer-specific (Cruise or Waymo) trends in these patterns. This method builds upon the evaluation of crash scenarios by considering the sequential nature of crashes, incorporating crash progression and contributing factors. The results highlight the current challenge faced by manufacturers in designing systems that are safe yet perform in a manner expected by human drivers. The proportional reduction of crash patterns involving rear-end collisions during left or right turns suggests that actions were taken by manufacturers to address the aforementioned challenge. However, other crash patterns have shown a proportional increase in recent years, such as collisions with objects and on narrow roads, with specific variations by manufacturers. These findings provide key insights for shaping future AV development, guiding public sector decisions, and building public trust in automation.

title: Gait-Adaptive Perceptive Humanoid Locomotion With Real-Time Under-Base Terrain Reconstruction
authors: Haolin Song, Hongbo Zhu, Tao Yu, Yan Liu, Mingqi Yuan, Wengang Zhou, Hua Chen, Houqiang Li
abstract: For full-size humanoid robots, reliable locomotion on complex terrains—such as long staircases—remains challenging, even with recent advances in reinforcement-learning-based control. In such settings, limited perception, ambiguous terrain cues, and insufficient adaptation of gait timing can cause even a single misplaced or mistimed step to result in rapid loss of balance. We introduce a perceptive locomotion framework that merges terrain sensing, gait regulation, and whole-body control into a single reinforcement learning policy. A downward-facing depth camera mounted under the base observes the support region around the feet, and a compact U-Net reconstructs a dense egocentric height map from each frame in real time, operating at the same frequency as the control loop. The perceptual height map, together with proprioceptive observations, is processed by a unified policy that produces joint commands and a global stepping-phase signal, allowing gait timing and whole-body posture to be adapted jointly to the commanded motion and local terrain geometry. We further adopt a single-stage successive teacher–student training scheme for efficient policy learning and knowledge transfer. Experiments conducted on a 31-DoF, 1.65 m humanoid robot demonstrate robust locomotion in both simulation and real-world settings, including forward and backward stair ascent and descent, as well as crossing a 46 cm gap. title: A Novel Digital Twin for Diesel Generator in Microgrids
authors: Renuka Loka, Mahmoud Kabalan, Thomas Holliday, Rakesh Shamrao Patekar, Mohanad Elsayed, Mohamed M. Zakaria Moustafa, Thomas Bozada
abstract: Diesel generators (DiGs) play a vital role in Micro grids (MG) to ensure resiliency and reliability; however, accurate modeling of their behavior in both grid-connected and islanded modes is challenging due to limited experimental and manufacturer data. Standard simulation models often fail to capture real world dynamics, leading to inaccurate results. To address these limitations, this paper presents an adaptive digital twin (DT) model for the 62.5kVA DiG unit at the Center for Microgrid Research (CMR). The DT model, capable of grid-connected and islanded operations, is developed and experimentally validated within the CMR's Microgrid infrastructure. The proposed DT leverages a novel adaptive parameter methodology to dynamically reflect the generator's behavior in varying operating conditions for both transient and steady-state responses. The results confirm that the adaptive DT accurately replicates the dynamic response of the real-world industry-grade DiG. The DT offers a robust modeling platform for advanced MG studies that involve DiGs under multiple operation modes.
