title: Wideband Full-Polarization Reconfigurable Antenna for Intelligent IoT Applications
authors: Changjiang Li, Jianxing Li, Baihong Chi, Ya Kong, Jianhe Wang, Xiaoming Chen
abstract: novel wideband antenna with five reconfigurable polarization states is presented for intelligent IoT applications, where polarization agility can be exploited by a higher-layer controller to enhance link reliability in dynamic multipath environments. To achieve wideband performance across all polarization states, coupling mechanisms are strategically introduced into the radiation structure, feeding structure, and feeding network simultaneously. Firstly, through equivalent circuit analysis, shorting pins, metal strips, and slots are integrated into the radiation structure. The coupling mechanisms excite first- and second-order frequency responses, resulting in significant gain improvement and overlapping bandwidth enhancement. Secondly, a co-planar capacitive feeding structure is implemented into the feeding network to improve impedance matching. Subsequently, weakly coupled transmission lines are deployed within both differential and full-polarization feeding networks. Such a configuration ensures wide overlapping bandwidth performance throughout all five polarization states by suppressing phase shift errors. Finally, by controlling the ON/OFF states of PIN diodes, the feeding network generates desired phase differences, enabling the proposed antenna to be reconfigured between five polarization states, i.e., linearly polarization (LP) with three orientations, left-hand circularly polarization (LHCP), and right-hand circularly polarization (RHCP). Experimental results demonstrate that the antenna achieves an operating bandwidth of 8–13 GHz (47.6%), with axial ratio (AR) < 3.0 dB and in-band gain fluctuation < 3.0 dB. Characterized by wide bandwidth, full-polarization agility, and standard fabrication, the design presents a viable solution for demanding multi-polarization applications in industrial Internet of Things (IoT) scenarios.

title: A Federated Learning Framework for Sustainable Boro Rice Yield Prediction Using Multi-Regional Agro-Climatic Data
authors: Firoze Maliha, Gazi Tahsina Sharmin Jahin, Arfanul Islam, M. Jamshed Alam Patwary, Mohammad Shamsul Arefin
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Boro rice, the primary dry-season crop in Bangladesh, plays a critical role in national food security. Accurate prediction of yield is critical in the context of escalating climate uncertainty and mounting population pressure. This study will propose a federated machine learning model that leverages 25 years (2000-2024) of agro-climatic and production data across six major divisions of Bangladesh to predict Boro rice yield. A novel dataset was built from satellite-extracted environmental characteristics and ground-truth yield information from the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics and NASA POWER. The local-level performance of ten regression models was compared, in which SGD regressor was the best performer(up to R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.978). A Federated Averaging (FedAvg) approach was used for decentralized learning with linear SGD regressors while preserving privacy of the data and improving generalization. The global federated model had convergence with lesser validation MSE (0.0953) and higher R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>(0.871) than any single-division model, outperforming local models. The addition of federated learning to rich agro-climatic data offers a scalable, privacy-protecting solution for crop yield estimation, with impactful agro-planning and climate resilience implications for Bangladesh.

title: Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Approach for Detecting Major Depressive Disorder from EEG Signals
authors: Swetha K, Sriraam J, G.Ramya, G.Divya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a prevalent psychiatric disease that needs to be diagnosed properly at the appropriate time for fruitful intervention. A novel method using a Multi-Granularity Graph Convolution Network (MG-GCN) model to classify depression degree from images of EEG signal is introduced in this work. The architecture consists of image processing techniques such as median filtering and enhancement using ESRGAN to improve the clarity of the signal. A Decision Tree classifier is used to classify depressive states into three levels of severity. Model performance is measured using structural similarity (SSIM), peak signal-to- noise ratio (PSNR), and classification accuracy, reflecting the ability of the model in the extraction and discrimination of functionally relevant brain activity patterns.MG-GCN architecture utilizes multi-level graph structures for preserving strong and weak brain connectivity features to facilitate longer learning of brain topologies. It is implemented with a user-friendly graphical interface in MATLAB, by which EEG images can be uploaded and received with real-time diagnostic results. In addition to real-time prediction, visualization was improved, and performance metrics to assist clinical assessment, quick documentation is also enabled by automatic reporting of the system. The deployment is a clear trend towards making EEG-based psychological diagnosis smart and accessible.

title: An Efficient 32-Bit Carry Look Ahead Adder using PFAL for Low Power Circuits
authors: Shaik Hibza, C. Padma
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Adders are digital circuits used in VLSI (Very Large Scale Integration) architecture that carry out arithmetic operations, particularly addition, on binary values. They are employed in a wide range of devices, such as memory systems, digital signal processors, and microprocessors. Logic gates that accept two binary values as inputs and output a binary sum make up an adder. These days, designing low power VLSI circuits heavily relies on low power circuits. Adiabatic circuits explain reversible logic, or the reuse of the same, which results in power savings. Using the traditional approach, CMOS circuits are utilized to lower circuit power dissipation. A number of adiabatic techniques were developed to address the shortcomings of CMOS circuits. These techniques use charging and discharging to further reduce power dissipation. Efficient Charge Recovery Logic (ECRL) and Positive Feedback Adiabatic logic (PFAL) are the methods employed. Arithmetic operations, such as adder and multiplier, require full adders. In this paper, we will examine the designs of adiabatic logic and develop a new complete adder employing PFAL logic, followed by simulations. Consequently, the circuits' effectiveness is displayed and contrasted utilizing the nano meter technologies. By lowering the amount of circuit delay, the Carry Look a Ahead Adder— also referred to as FAST ADDER—also plays a significant role. Since delay is a significant factor in LOW POWER VLSI CIRCUITS, the power dissipation in the full adder is decreased by employing the adiabatic technique. When comparing ECRL and PFAL, the power dissipation is decreased in both, but PFAL is somewhat more lowered. Tanner EDA Tool simulates every circuit utilizing 22 nm Technology.

title: The Journey from 4G to 6G: A Systematic Investigation of Wireless Networks Focusing on 6G
authors: Rakib Rayhan, Md. Mehedi Hassan, Abu Saleh Molla, Sabbir Hossain, Md.Shariful Islam, Md. Shahjahan Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: The rapid evolution of mobile communication technologies from 4G to the envisioned 6G systems has substantially enhanced network capabilities, including data throughput, latency, connection density, and intelligence. Fourth generation (4G) networks brought broadband internet access with mobility, while fifth generation (5G) systems enabled ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC), massive machine-type communication (mMTC), and enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB). However, the accelerating demand for real-time data, intelligent applications, and seamless user experience is pushing the limits of 5G infrastructure. Sixth generation (6G) wireless networks are expected to operate in sub-terahertz (Sub-THz) and terahertz (THz) bands, supporting peak data rates up to 1 Tbps, latencies below 0.1 ms, and connection densities exceeding 10⁷ devices/km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative analysis of 4G, 5G, and 6G technologies based on key performance indicators such as user experience data rate, peak data rate, latency, connection density, and spectral efficiency. It also explores architectural trends and application domains unique to 6G, including holographic communication, immersive extended reality (XR), remote healthcare, and AI-native networking. The analysis offers valuable insights for researchers and industry stakeholders to better understand the technological evolution and challenges of the transition to 6G.

title: HLE-DLM: A Hybrid Legal-Empowerment Deep Learning Model for Evaluating Labour Law Implications on Transgender Persons After the Transgender Persons Act
authors: R. Arun Kumar, Asha Sundaram, Dr.S.K.Kamalakhannan
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: The enactment of the Transgender Persons Act marked a critical milestone in addressing systemic discrimination and fostering inclusivity for transgender individuals. This study presents the Hybrid Legal-Empowerment Deep Learning Model (HLE-DLM), a robust framework designed to evaluate the implications of labor laws on transgender individuals post-enactment of the Transgender Persons Act. By leveraging a hybrid architecture combining Legal Context Encoder (LCE) and Empowerment Discriminator (ED), the model analyzes legal and socio-economic data to provide actionable insights. HLE-DLM achieves exceptional accuracy of 96.77% for legal context analysis and 93.12% for socio-economic impact prediction, showcasing its reliability in handling diverse datasets. The methodology involves preprocessing annotated legal and demographic datasets, extracting meaningful features using NLP techniques, and integrating multimodal data for a holistic evaluation. Key findings include a significant reduction in discrimination-related themes (from 58% to 18%) and substantial improvements in socio-economic indicators like employment rate (+23%) and workplace diversity (+21%). The model’s interpretability, achieved through attention mechanisms, enables stakeholders to focus on critical legal phrases, enhancing trust and applicability. HLE-DLM offers a comprehensive tool for policymakers, legal professionals, and advocacy groups, driving inclusivity and equality in workplaces. Future iterations aim to expand the model's scope to include global labor law datasets for cross-country comparisons.

title: Design and Performance Optimization of a Compact Microstrip Patch antenna for C-Band Applications
authors: Zarin Nushiba, Nirzar Barua, Md Nazmul Islam, Saikat Barua, MD. Akter Hossain, Arafat Uddin
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: This paper presents a compact microstrip patch antenna, specially for C-band application. The proposed antenna is designed using a tilted ‘H’ shaped slot along with a circular section in the middle of the patch. These engineered slots help to make the proper radiation distribution towards the antenna and achieve the operating band at 5.86 GHz. The antenna is tailored by using copper patch on the FR-4 substrate and a remarkable 48% size reduction is observed in the antenna geometry. At the operating frequency, the antenna exhibits a reflection coefficient of -37.45dB as well as a 140 MHz bandwidth. The ultimate gain at the operating point of 6.49dBi ensures its high directivity and enables the further operation in efficient beamforming and beam steering applications of the advanced wireless communication system. The antenna efficiently radiates with the maximum efficiency of 79% between the operating frequency supporting the C-band, opening its path of real-life application in as satellite communication, high-speed Wi-Fi, cordless telephony, and radar systems for security and weather monitoring.

title: A Hybrid Region-based Data Acquisition Approach for Optimizing Energy Efficiency in UAV-Assisted Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Rifah Tasnia Joita, Monir Hossen
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: With the integration of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) in environmental monitoring, the growing requirement for large-scale monitoring becomes a critical challenge due to limited battery power and storage in sensor nodes. While WSNs with integrated unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) tend to be effective for prolonging network lifetime, their deployment in the lineof-sight proximity incorporates redundant energy usage and system latency. To address this, we propose a hybrid region-aware UAV-assisted (HR-UAV) data acquisition strategy that divides the network area into two regions— near region and far region, with respect to the sink node. The near region nodes incorporate direct transmission of the data to the sink nodes, while the far region utilizes a UAV that plans an optimized route according to the Greedy algorithm with variation and insertion strategies. It collects data from a subset of sensor nodes using compressive sensing to reduce the data load in the UAV. The sink node reconstructs the data with the help of a learned sparsifying basis from historical data. Simulation results show that HR-UAV achieves energy efficiency of 9.17% –19.886%, reduces error of 11.15%–0.003%, reduces path length by 10.28%–25.64% and lowers the latency by 7.54%–25%.

title: SignNet-Nano: Efficient Sign Language Recognition for Real-Time Edge Deployment
authors: Rifat Zabin, Md. Riasat Tanjim Hossain, Khandaker Foysal Haque, K M Rumman
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Real-time american sign language (ASL) alphabet recognition can enable inclusive communication on next-generation edge devices like virtual reality (VR) headsets and smart glasses. However, existing models are often too computationally demanding for such platforms, resulting in fast battery depletion and degraded performance. To address this challenge, we introduce SignNet-Nano, an ultra-lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN), tailored specifically for efficient ASL alphabet recognition on constrained edge hardware. The proposed model integrates depthwise separable (DS) convolutions, squeeze-and-excitation (SE) attention, and global average pooling (GAP) to achieve high accuracy with a compact architecture comprising only < 20K parameters and < 0.1MB model size. Unlike prior work, SignNet-Nano is explicitly designed with deployment efficiency as a primary goal, enabling real-time inference with minimal performance degradation while requiring significantly less energy, latency, computation, and memory usage than state-of-the-art (SOTA) lightweight edge models. We profile inference performance in terms of Floating Point Operations (FLOPs), inference latency, frames per second (FPS), and memory footprint on a diverse set of platforms, including three edge devices— Jetson Nano, Jetson Xavier NX, and Raspberry Pi 4— as well as three high-performance systems— Apple Mac M3 (MPS backend), NVIDIA RTX 4070 GPU, and an Intel Core i7 12th Gen CPU. Experimental results show that SignNet-Nano achieves classification accuracy within 1% of the best-performing baseline while reducing inference time (i.e., latency) and FLOPs by up to 73.7% and 97.1%, respectively, while improving the energy efficiency by up to 79.3%.

title: An Efficient Machine Learning Technique for Anomaly Detection on Industrial Big Data
authors: Prakhar Sharma, Anshu Tiwari, Damodar Tiwari, Kailash Patidar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel and effective machine learning-based method to detect anomalies in industrial big data, based on a supervised ANN architecture. The proposed model is tailored to deal with high dimensional, noisy and imbalanced datasets commonly seen in industrial settings. With systematic preprocessing (including normalization and PCA), the model achieves better accuracy and fast convergence. Comprehensive simulations show the superiority of the ANN over conventional models including SVM, Isolation Forest and Autoencoder in terms of performance, accuracy, robustness to noise, scalability and interpretability. Real time latency tests and SHAP-based feature analysis additionally confirm the deployability of the model. The results presented in this paper point to the ANN system as a trustworthy, scalable and interpretable solution for real-world industrial anomaly detection work.

title: Ensemble Learning Approaches for Early and Accurate Detection of Alzheimer’s disease
authors: S Selvaragini, Gnanajeyaraman Rajaram
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD)is a chronic neurological disorder and the most prevalent type of dementia that profoundly impairs an individual’s cognitive and physical functions. Using the OASIS dataset, this paper suggests a thorough ensemble learning approach for AD prediction that makes use of voting, bagging, and stacking classifiers. To improve model performance, the dataset is given to significant preprocessing, which includes data cleaning, normalization, missing value imputation, and advanced feature selection methods including Mutual Information and mRMR.Our proposed model achieved the highest accuracy of 98%, exhibiting superior performance to other existing methods such as Random Forest with median imputation (86.92%), BrainNet2D (92%), and Modified Capsule Network (92.39%). These outcomes show the effectiveness of our proposed model in predicting AD, facilitating better clinical decisions, and enhancing patient health care.

title: Classification and Detection of ADHD using Deep Machine Learning Model
authors: Ritesh kumar, Rajeev ranjan, Sourabh Boruah, Anuj Kumar, Anant Krishan Pun
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: This study presents a deep learning-based framework for the classification and detection of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) using EEG signals. Key features were extracted and analyzed from EEG data that have been preprocessed with advanced filtering and artifact removal techniques. After that, a variety of hybrid deep learning models are used to perform the analysis. Of the many different kinds of models that were evaluated, a CNN + Transformer architecture achieved the best results—with a validation accuracy of 99.93% and a training accuracy of 99.52%. This model was particularly good at identifying the kinds of spatial and temporal features in the EEG data that are implicated in ADHD. An impressive result was also obtained by a different model architecture— Autoencoder + CNN + Transformer—that produced a 99.54% validation accuracy.

title: Advancements in Melanoma Detection: A Deep Learning Approach for Improved Diagnosis and Comparison with Human Performance
authors: Sharmila Shanthi Sequeira, Vikitha H, Varsha V, S Hari Priya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Melanoma represents a severe variant of skin cancer characterized by its rapid progression, and remains a significant concern for public health, with early detection being crucial for better patient outcomes. In this work, we systematically examine various approaches and current advancements related to melanoma detection, focusing on both traditional image analysis techniques with the integration of deep learning algorithms such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to enhance detection accuracy. It highlights ongoing challenges in accurately diagnosing melanoma, particularly the difficulty in distinguishing between benign and malignant lesions, and underlines the necessity of high-quality, diverse datasets for reliable assessments. The review explores established diagnostic approaches such as pattern analysis, rule-based systems (e.g., the ABCD rule), statistical feature extraction methods, as well as CNN-based models, all aimed at improving diagnostic precision. Additionally, integrating clinical information like patient history and demographic factors has shown potential to complement image-based assessment, further enhancing diagnostic performance. The findings emphasize the value of comprehensive diagnostic strategies—combining detailed image examination, relevant clinical data, and advanced deep learning techniques—in advancing melanoma detection and diagnosis. The paper also introduces a novel element by evaluating differences between expert dermatologists’ diagnostic performance and standard algorithmic or AI-based assessments via a custom-designed website. This comparative approach fosters a deeper understanding of prevailing diagnostic capabilities in melanoma detection. Thus, the developed framework highlights a promising strategy for early skin cancer identification and intervention, which could enhance patient well-being while ensuring more effective healthcare resource utilization.

title: A TransLSTM-Based Approach to Employee Management and Human Resource Optimization
authors: L. Vijayakumar, B. Kannadasan, Bramah Hazela, Arpit Pandey, D. Suganthi, Deepan Chakravarthi A. V.
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Enhancing organizational performance and strategic decision-making requires efficient personnel management and human resource optimisation. Our goal in this project is to improve HR procedures by using suggestion mining and intelligent data analysis. To guarantee the quality and dependability of the dataset, data cleaning was first carried out using common data preprocessing techniques. Because of its strong convergence behavior and capacity to avoid local optima, the CS Algorithm was used to enhance the human resource management scheme's global optimisation capabilities. Additionally, they present TransLSTM, a unique hybrid model for suggestion mining that combines Transformer design with LSTM networks. This model captures both local and global relationships in HR-related text data by utilising the sequential learning capabilities of LSTM in conjunction with Transformers' contextual knowledge. The model is able to precisely detect and extract useful recommendations thanks to the combined strengths of these architectures. According to experimental results, the TransLSTM model outperforms current models in comparable tasks, achieving an amazing accuracy of 99.20%. All things considered, combining CS for optimisation with TransLSTM for intelligent suggestion mining offers a potent way to develop staff management systems and enhance HR decision-making.

title: An Efficient GPS-Based Path Planning Method for Autonomous Tractor Navigation
authors: Osama Abdul Hannan, Golam Mostafa Rabby, Md. Imam Mahdi, Abdul Owadud Raton, Abdulla Al-Kibria
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Agricultural automation is vital for overcoming labor shortages and enhancing field efficiency. This study presents two GPS-based path planning strategies, Spiral and S-shape patterns, for an autonomous tractor operating in a rectangular field. The results demonstrate that the Spiral pattern achieves complete field coverage with substantially less overlap of 26 meters and a shorter cultivation time of 3.51 minutes compared to the S-shaped pattern. The Spiral path covers approximately 583.6 meters with efficient movement, whereas the S-shape layout involves extra travel to complete the field. These findings indicate that the Spiral navigation strategy offers a more efficient solution for autonomous field cultivation, highlighting its potential benefit in the context of precision agriculture.

title: Coarse Alignment Method Using Manifold Optimization for Sins on a Rocking Base
authors: Fujun Pei, Haoyang Li
abstract: This paper proposes a coarse alignment method using manifold optimization to solve the initial alignment problem of the strapdown inertial navigation system (SINS) on a rocking base. In this method, the initial coarse alignment of SINS is transformed from the constrained optimization problem in Euclidean space to an unconstrained optimization problem in Manifold space. There are two innovations in this method: the first is the optimization method of gradient descent in Euclidean space, which is reviewed and extended to manifold space. By combining the trust region method with the Barzilai-Borwein method, the optimal selection of the iterative update step on the tangent space of the manifold is realized, which ensures the efficient and stable convergence of the algorithm. Secondly, the Cayley transform is used to construct the retraction mapping, and its closed form analytic solution and structure preservation characteristics are used to effectively suppress the error accumulation caused by numerical approximation, to ensure that the iterative points on the tangent space of the manifold are mapped to the manifold space. The experiment results indicate that the proposed coarse alignment method performs better than the existing methods.

title: Adaptive Optimization of Deep Learning Models: Leveraging Hardware-Software Co-Design for Performance
authors: Shubh Jani
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: The advancement of deep learning models is far beyond the current computational demands and has even gone beyond the traditional hardware improvements predicted by Moore’s Law. While GPUs and AI accelerators like NVIDIA Tesla and Apple’s Neural Engine have better energy efficiency for deep neural networks (DNNs) there is still a disparity between hardware and software optimizations. Current optimization methods like pruning, quantization, and sparsification are static and are unable to adapt to dynamic workloads or heterogeneous architectures. This paper proposes an adaptive hardware-software co-design framework to bridge this gap, dynamically optimizing DNN configurations based on real-time hardware profiling, task complexity, and energy constraints. We benchmark diverse architectures (CPUs, GPUs, AI accelerators) and models (VGG16, ResNet50, EfficientNet) to evaluate performance and energy efficiency. Our results demonstrate that GPU tensor-core optimization reduces energy consumption by 48–120× compared to CPUs, while lightweight models like EfficientNet achieve 4–6× efficiency gains over complex architectures. Software optimizations, when hardware-aware, yield up to 96% energy reduction (e.g., pruning on AI accelerators). However, optimizations that are mismatches (e.g., sparsification on CPUs) can degrade performance. The proposed co-design framework achieves Pareto-optimal trade-offs by enabling scalable and energy-efficient DNN deployment across edge devices.

title: Enhancing Wheat Disease Identification with Fine-Tuned EfficientNetB3 for Sustainable Crop Protection
authors: Rashi Nimesh Kumar Dhenia, Raghavendra Sridhar, Vishnu Kant, Ishva Jitendrakumar Kanani, Deepak Banerjee, Gaurav Sharma
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: Global wheat production faces severe threats to its stability because Septoria along with stripe rust infections affect wheat leaves. Crop management depends heavily on quick and correct identification of these plant diseases. This paper develops a deep learning convention that employs an EfficientNetB3 architecture trained through finetuning to identify wheat leaf diseases. The open-source Kaggle platform serves as the dataset source with classes of healthy and both disease subclasses Septoria and stripe rust. Pre-processing and data augmentation methods received extensive use to enhance model ability to generalize. The researchers modified EfficientNetB3 by implementing dense layers together with batch normalization and dropout to both improve classification effectiveness and reduce overfitting risk. Standard evaluation performance metrics such as accuracy along with precision, recall and F1-score were used to assess the model during training and evaluation. The new method proved successful at detecting wheat leaf diseases by reaching high precision rates in disease classification. The proposed study advances automated disease diagnosis systems for agriculture, which promotes sustainable farming alongside responsible production and climate resilience and rural innovation as well as pandemic intervention to minimize crop losses and ultimately support better health and economic development in agricultural areas.

title: Breast Cancer Detection In UltraSound Images Using DenseNet121 Model
authors: A. Yashashree, B. Charan, B. Aakash, B. Sudarshan Naidu, Prakash Kumar Sarangi, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: cancer in breast is one of the growing reason for death in women worldwide, effective treatment planning now depends on early and accurate detection.Asymmetry in the shape of the breast, genetic problems, or aberrant cell growth are some of the causes of breast cancer.At first, doctors can screen for this, but it became more difficult as the number of cases rose. In order to help radiologists spot even the smallest anomalies, such as asymmetries, in ultrasound or mammography images, advanced computer-aided diagnostic (CAD) systems are becoming more and more crucial. This study proposes a novel multi-class classification framework for detecting and interpreting asymmetries using DenseNet, a potent deep neural network (CNN) has given 95% accuracy in medical imaging tasks. DenseNet is used to capture fine-grained tissue composition variations that are often missed by traditional CNNs and may indicate early pathological changes. As a result, DenseNet can take advantage of the hierarchical spatial features present in breast tissue.

title: Temporal Relational GNN for Coordinated Multi-Drone Surveillance
authors: Suganya T, Preethi R, Saranya U, R Nithiyavathy, Akshya. J, M Sundarrajan, Mani Deepak Choudhry
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Multi-drone surveillance is increasingly vital in environmental studies, disaster security, and intelligent safety applications, but achieving real-time, scalable, and adaptive cooperation remains challenging due to dynamic air environments and the need to model temporal relationships between agents. To address this, we propose a Temporal Relational Graph Neural Network (TR-GNN) that represents drones as graph nodes with time-varying edges, enabling relation-wise interaction learning, neighbor awareness, and both self and surrounding state transition memory. TR-GNN supports role-based attention, failure-aware rerouting, anomaly detection, and energy-based retreat in a decentralized, data-driven manner. Deployed in a simulated Google Colab environment with dynamic trajectory visualization, metric monitoring, and adaptive role assignment, TR-GNN achieved 92.4% accuracy, 24.6 ms latency, and 19.3 mJ energy cost improvements of up to 9.9% and 35% over baselines demonstrating its strength as a real-time UAV coordination system, with future work aimed at neuromorphic chip deployment, heterogeneous fleet adaptation, and 3D airspace integration.

title: Deep Learning-Based Non-Traditional Method for Multi-Focus Image Fusion in Surveillance Systems
authors: Prabhishek Singh, Shailesh Bhosekar, Deepak Garg, Manoj Diwakar, Aditya Joshi, Neeraj Kumar Pandey
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: The depth of field of optical lenses may be increased with the help of multi-focus image fusion, which takes many images of the same subject with varying degrees of focus and combines them into a single, focused image. With the fast evolution of image representation theories and methods like multi-scale geometric analysis, sparse representation, deep learning, etc., significant strides have been made in this area in recent years. Due to the limitations of incorrect image capture and the lack of clarity and quality of different settings, the demand for image fusion has risen dramatically in recent years. The first part of this study is a review of the many different approaches to multi-focus image fusion that have already been developed. Keeping current with the state of the art, taxonomy is provided to organize existing approaches into four primary classes: transform domain methods, spatial domain methods, hybrid methods that combine transform domain and spatial domain, and deep learning methods. Different fusion techniques are shown and reviewed for each classification. These image fusion techniques are practically used in visual sensor networks (VSN) for efficient surveillance and motion tracking. Then, using a multi-focus image dataset and well-known objective fusion criteria, a comparative analysis of the fusion algorithms is carried out. A few common objective assessment indicators are also discussed in depth, and both the subjective and objective evaluation criteria are provided. The future research directions and opportunities for multi-focus image fusion are covered in the last section of this paper.

title: An Attention-Optimized Enhanced YOLOv11 Architecture for Real-Time Breast Cancer Detection
authors: Mohammed Saifuddin Munna, Nazia Sultana Plabon, Rafa Akter Ema
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Breast cancer remains the most commonly diagnosed cancer among women worldwide, with delayed detection significantly impacting survival rates. While deep learning offers promise for early diagnosis, existing models face a critical trade-off between accuracy and speed, often failing to detect subtle malignancies or meet clinical workflow demands. This study presents Enhanced YOLOv11, an attention optimized architecture designed to bridge this gap through three key innovations: (1) a coordinate attention backbone that amplifies malignant features while suppressing tissue noise, (2) dynamic anchor tuning optimized for lesion morphology, and (3) a hybrid Wise-IoU + Focal Loss addressing class imbalance and ambiguous boundaries. Evaluated on 4,015 expert annotated mammograms (CBIS-DDSM), Enhanced YOLOv11 achieved 99.1% mean average precision (mAP) with 0.4 false positives per image excel radiologist performance in controlled trials. The model demonstrated exceptional sensitivity for early stage tumors (99.5%) and sub-5mm lesions (83% recall), while maintaining real-time inference speeds (58 FPS) through TensorRT optimization. These results represent a 1.9% mAP improvement over prior state-of-the-art models. By unifying clinical insight with architectural innovation, this work establishes a new paradigm for medical AI domain specific co design that delivers both diagnostic precision and practical deployability. The system’s performance and efficiency position it as a transformative tool for global breast cancer screening programs, with the potential to prevent thousands of missed diagnoses annually.

title: Assessment of Machine Learning-Based Diagnostic Models for Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Neeru, Prashant Upadhyaya, Gaganjot Kaur
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: The significant change in lifestyle brought by the modern technology is affecting the child development to a great extent. In this fast-paced life with busy schedules, children are often kept occupied with screens, have limited access to outdoor spaces, and experience reduced community interaction. Consequently, this will affect social, emotional, and cognitive growth, as well as delayed development in many children. This has increased the severity and visibility of autism related neurodevelopmental challenges. This paper focuses on the current study conducted by researchers to detect Autism Spectrum Disorder using state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms. For this, four machine learning models are used for evaluation. They are Support Vector Machine (SVM), Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbor (K-NN) and Naive Bayes(NB). It has been observed that LR model achieved 100% accuracy for the toddler dataset.

title: An Efficient Video Compression and Encoding Approach for Wireless Communication System
authors: Ashwini S.Dhamoji, S.B.Akkole
publish: 2025 Global Conference on Information Technology and Communication Networks (GITCON)
abstract: With the rapid growth of video traffic in wireless networks, efficient transmission of high-quality video over wireless systems is increasingly challenging. The need for high data rates, low latency, and error resilience in video transmission calls for advanced compression techniques. Hence, this paper proposes Encoding-Error Aware Compression (EEAC) approach to address these challenges. The EEAC method combines Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to enhance encoding and compression efficiency, reduce transmission errors, and maintain high reconstruction quality at the receiver. Using a standard foreman sequence for evaluation, the performance of the EEAC approach was compared with existing methods. The results demonstrate that EEAC outperforms the existing approaches in terms of Bit Error Rate (BER), Symbol Error Rate (SER), and compression efficiency. Specifically, EEAC achieved a 37% improvement in BER, a 22% improvement in SER, and a 40% improvement in compression efficiency, when compared with existing approaches. These findings showcase EEAC’s robustness in handling noisy environments and its suitability for high-demand wireless applications. The proposed approach is particularly beneficial for bandwidth-constrained 5G systems and offers a scalable solution for high-quality video transmission.

title: Enhancing Breast Cancer Detection Using SVM and Explainable AI
authors: J. Anushree, GR. Ashisha, Utpal Chandra De, Bibhuti Bhusan Dash, X. Anitha Mary, C.Karthik, Matam Mohan Babu, P. Jyotheeswari, Sudhansu Shekhar Patra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: Currently, among all cancers, breast cancer is among the leading diagnosed cancers and ranks as a significant contributor to female mortality according to global statistics. Breast cancer may be Highly treatable when detected in the initial stages. Tumors associated with breast cancer are of two types: malignant and benign. Malignant tumor pose a greater threat compared to benign tumors. Therefore, early identification of tumor type is important for providing the patient with appropriate treatment. Machine learning (ML) has become a significance tool in medical diagnostics. In this paper we use Wisconsin Breast Cancer Dataset (WBCD) to create a Support Vector Machine (SVM) based classification model that differentiates between benign and malignant tumors is compared to give more accuracy the other classifiers. The SVM model achieves a 98.25 percentage accuracy rate, demonstrating its potential in predicting breast cancer. Additionally, we investigate strategies for hyperparameter tuning and feature selection for boosting the algorithm's capability. In order to tackle the challenges of interpretability in ML models, we employ Explainable AI (XAI) techniques such as LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) and SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations). The classification technique aims to identify breast cancer at an early stage.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Detecting Suspicious Activities in Video Surveillance
authors: Romana Nourin Nipa, Tasmim Jamal Joti, Md Jakir Hossain, Md Jubaer Rahman, Md. Zahidul Islam, Md Alamgir Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Computing, Applications and Systems (COMPAS)
abstract: Over the last few years, video surveillance has become an essential means of ensuring security and safety in numerous domains. However, the detection of unusual and suspicious behaviors or movements in surveillance video still poses a significant problem due to the dynamically complex nature of human activity and context. Traditional methods excel at spatial feature extraction but lack temporal modeling, limiting their ability to detect suspicious activity. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a novel deep-learning architecture called ConvGRU, combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU). This approach builds on the fact that CNNs are inherently capable of extracting spatial features, while GRUs seek to capture temporal dependencies; hence, the proposed method is more general in a framework than using CNNs only for crime and suspicious activity detection. In experiments on multiple video surveillance datasets, the model achieves an increased accuracy of 99.52%, in particular it is effective in distinguishing among suspicious behaviors.

title: Cross-Dataset Generalizable Paddy Leaf Disease Detection via ViT–CNN Fusion and Domain-Specific Preprocessing
authors: Vishnu Gandhi V, Deepa J
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT)
abstract: One of the biggest threats to world food security is the impact of paddy leaf diseases including Blast, Bacterial Blight, Brown Spot, and Leaf Scald on rice production and quality. Using an explainable hybrid Vision Transformer-Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) classification model, optimization-driven feature selection, multi-level feature extraction, and hybrid preprocessing are all components of the new Paddy Leaf Disease Detection Framework that is proposed in this study. In order to improve the visibility of illness regions and decrease overfitting, the preprocessing pipeline integrates conventional and GAN-based data augmentation, edge detection, Gaussian smoothing, and domain-specific color space transformations. In order to capture both local and global illness patterns, attention processes are used to modify shape features, texture descriptors (GLCM, LBP), and multi-level CNN features. Optimization of classification efficiency is achieved by the use of the Beetle Antennae Search (BAS) method, which finds the most discriminative features. The effectiveness of the suggested architecture is proven by extensive tests conducted on the Rice Leaf Disease Dataset, PlantVillage Dataset, and Paddy Leaf Disease Dataset. It surpasses CNN (92.5% accuracy), ResNet50 (90.1% accuracy), VGG16 (88.4% accuracy), and SVM (85.7% accuracy) with its 95.3% accuracy, 94.2% precision, 96.1% recall, and 95.1% F1-score. The model's best SHAP-based interpretability score of 0.87 and quickest inference time of 0.03s attest to its viability for use in real-time scenarios. Robustness in varied contexts is highlighted by the low performance degradation indicated by cross-dataset generalization tests. This system provides a workable answer to the problem of paddy disease early detection and control by integrating computational economy, explainability, and high accuracy. Improved crop monitoring, less yield loss, and more sustainable rice farming practices on a worldwide scale can result from its incorporation into precision agricultural systems.

title: Rule-Based Protein Classification through Multi-Phase Feature Extraction Technique_supp1-3663211.pdf
authors: SUPRATIV SAHA
abstract: Protein sequence classification is a fundamental step toward functional annotation and biological analysis; however, most of the existing approaches rely on computationally expensive models or flat feature integration with limited interpretability. This paper proposes a multi-phase rule-based protein classification framework that hierarchically integrates biologically meaningful features. An early-exit decision strategy is employed. Feature extraction is performed across four progressive phases comprising chemical properties, hydropathy characteristics, behavioral sequence patterns through n-gram and six-letter exchange encoding, and functional attributes via normalized distance-based encoding. Family-specific knowledge matrices constructed exclusively from training data enable deterministic min–max rule evaluation at each phase for efficient candidate pruning and early termination. Experiments conducted on 8,555 human protein sequences spanning ten families achieve an average classification accuracy of 97.66%. 5-fold, 25-fold, and 45-fold cross-validation statistically confirm performance stability under class-imbalanced conditions. Further cross-species validation on zebrafish and mouse protein datasets yields accuracies of 96.11% and 94.89%, respectively, demonstrating robust generalization across diverse biological distributions. Comparative evaluation against machine-learning-based and transformer-based baselines shows that the proposed framework achieves a superior accuracy-efficiency trade-off while maintaining an overall time complexity of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(n\log n)$</tex-math></inline-formula>.

title: InSAR Phase Errors due to Range Misregistrations
authors: Fan Yang, Cunren Liang, Yuhang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: High quality InSAR measurements require precise and accurate range coregistration both between the reference and the secondary SAR images, and between the reference SAR image and the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) used for computing topographic phase. However, this requirement is not invariably satisfied due to the occurrence of range misregistrations. The range misregistration can occur between the reference image and the DEM, between the reference and secondary images, or due to the inhomogeneity within the range resolution cell. Our analysis reveals that, apart from the decorrelation effects, the effects of all three misregistration types ultimately reduce to that of an equivalent misregistration between the reference image and the DEM, which manifests as a phase error. Moreover, a closure phase error can be induced by the InSAR phase errors from the range misregistration between the reference and secondary images, as well as the inhomogeneity of the range resolution cell. We derive the InSAR and closure phase errors from both geometric and signal theory perspectives, assuming a homogeneously distributed target. We further extend the derivation to different types of targets. The derived InSAR and closure phase errors are confirmed by simulation and real-data experiments.

title: Opportunistic Gossip Learning-Aided Collaborative Physical Layer Authentication for Internet of Vehicles
authors: Jiandong Wang, Mubarak Umar, Shuangrui Zhao, Shuguang Wang, Minggang Zheng, Yulong Shen, Zhiwei Zhang, Yufeng Kang, Hafsa Kabir Ahmad
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traditional device authentication techniques relying only on a single device for authentication are susceptible to poor performance due to insufficient channel observations. Although these challenges are mitigated by centralized collaborative authentication schemes, such schemes assume that all users desire to learn the same model. They further assume constant collaborator presence, leading to poorly trained models in Internet of Vehicles (IoV) environments with fleeting encounters. Moreover, they are vulnerable to GPS spoofing attack. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Gossip Learning (GL)-based collaborative Physical Layer Authentication (PLA) scheme, where collaborators assist vehicles in authenticating transmitters by distributively training their Long Short-term Memory (LSTM) models using the location and Channel State Information (CSI) of the transmitters. The collaborators also improve their model instances by incorporating the learned experiences of other vehicles they meet opportunistically. Instead of using the claimed location of transmitters during authentication, which may be affected by the GPS spoofing attack, their Received Signal Strength (RSS) and Angle of Arrival (AoA) features are used to estimate their current location. The estimated location is then used to predict their current CSI for authentication. Moreover, we propose a distance-based GPS signal spoofing detection algorithm, which ensures that only collaborators not under GPS spoofing attack are selected for collaborative training. The simulation results from experiments conducted using realistic channel attributes obtained from the Quasi-Deterministic Radio channel Generator (QuaDRiGa) platform demonstrate the effectiveness of our system in IoV scenarios, underscoring its relevance to Intelligent Transportation Systems and its superiority over existing techniques.

title: Asymmetric Co-Training With Decoder–Head Decoupling for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Yuxin Tian, Muhan Shi, Jianxun Li, Bin Zhang, Min Qu, Yinxue Shi, Xian Yang, Min Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Semi-supervised learning reduces annotation costs in medical image segmentation by leveraging abundant unlabeled data alongside scarce labels. Most models adopt an encoder–decoder architecture with a task-specific segmentation head. While co-training is effective, existing frameworks suffer from intra-network coupling (decoder–head binding) and inter-network coupling (over-aligned predictions), which reduce prediction diversity and amplify confirmation bias–particularly for small structures, ambiguous boundaries, and anatomically variable regions. We propose AsyCo, an asymmetric co-training framework with two components. (1) Asymmetric Decoder Coupling implements decoder–head decoupling by dynamically remapping encoder–decoder features to non-default heads across branches, breaking intra-network coupling and creating diverse prediction paths without additional parameters. (2) Hierarchical Consistency Regularization converts this diversity into stable supervision by aligning (i) the two branches' final outputs along their default paths (branch-output consistency), (ii) predictions from different segmentation heads evaluated on identical decoder features (inter-head consistency), and (iii) intermediate encoder–decoder representations (representation consistency). Through these mechanisms, AsyCo explicitly mitigates both intra- and inter-network coupling, improving training stability and reducing confirmation bias. Extensive experiments on three clinical benchmarks under limited-label regimes demonstrate that AsyCo consistently outperforms nine state-of-the-art semi-supervised learning methods. These results indicate that AsyCo delivers accurate and reliable segmentation with minimal annotation, thereby enhancing the reliability of medical image analysis in real-world clinical practice.

title: On the Application of the IEC 60034-2-1 Standard to Line-Start Synchronous Reluctance Motors
authors: Fernando J. T. E. Ferreira, Pedro M. P. Guerreiro Guerreiro, Aníbal T. De Almeida
abstract: The IEC 60034-2-1 standard does not specify a method for three-phase line-start synchronous motors (LS-SynRMs). Although the direct input-output method can be easily applied, it does not specify how to correct the losses to a reference ambient temperature. This paper analyzes the applicability of the methods specified in the IEC 60034-2-1 standard to LS-SynRMs. The impact of ambient temperature on the full-load efficiency of LS-SynRMs is assessed. A method for segregating motor losses and correcting the average temperature and losses of the stator windings to a reference ambient temperature is proposed, ensuring that the stated full-load efficiency of the motor is determined accurately regardless of the ambient temperature in the laboratory where the tests are performed. Results from experiments conducted on two commercial LS-SynRMs are provided. It was observed that reducing the ambient temperature from 45 °C to 5 °C may increase the full-load efficiency of the tested LS-SynRMs by more than 1 percentage point, mainly due to the reduction of stator winding losses. Consequently, a motor manufacturer may consider testing this type of motor at lower ambient temperatures to achieve a higher efficiency class. Therefore, it is necessary to define a method for determining the efficiency of LS SynRMs that accounts for the correction of stator winding conduction losses to the standard reference ambient temperature of 25 °C. This paper intends to offer information that may contribute to overcoming the shortcomings and omissions of the IEC 60034-2-1 standard concerning the efficiency determination of LS-SynRMs, which is a relatively new technology on the market that is believed to be able to compete with line-operated induction motors in the low-power range, offering higher efficiency and constant operating speed.

title: Integrated Dynamic Routing and Off-Block Optimization Based on Taxiing Route Impedance for Airport Surface Operations
authors: Suwan Yin, Qing Wang, Ke Han, Washington Yotto Ochieng, Hongyu Yang, Wei Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This study develops an integrated dynamic routing and off-block (IDRO) optimization framework for real-time airport surface operations. Instead of relying on complex taxi time prediction models, the proposed approach employs a dynamic route impedance formulation as a practical heuristic to capture real-time congestion conditions on the airport surface. The impedance integrates domain-specific operational factors, including free flow taxi time, turning penalties, and potential aircraft conflicts, enabling real-time route evaluation and decision-making without extensive simulation. Building upon this impedance representation, the IDRO framework coordinates both taxi routing and off-block release timing under a real-time First-Come-First-Served (FCFS) principle. The approach was implemented and tested using a high-fidelity cellular automata simulator calibrated with operational data from Beijing Capital International Airport. Compared with real-world baseline operations, the proposed framework reduced average taxi time, flight delay, and taxi conflicts by 10.43%, 24.27%, and 31.82%, respectively. A comparative study with another similar approach in the literature also reveals the advantage of the proposed strategy. These results demonstrate the framework’s computational efficiency, consistent performance across scenarios, and strong potential for real-world deployment in large-scale airport environments.

title: GOTA-NU: Global Task Allocation with Non-deterministic Tasks and Unknown Users to Enhance Freeway Traffic Accident Detection
authors: Qian Cao, Zhihui Li, Haitao Li, Shirui Zhou, Yali Zhao, Jinghao Xie
abstract: Vehicular crowdsensing could enhance the traffic accident detection performance on freeways to the existing infrastructures by global task allocation. However, the uncertainty of traffic accidents and unknown of individual users bring difficulties for the task allocation. To address the problem, a global optimization method of task allocation with non-deterministic tasks and unknown users (GOTA-NU) is proposed. In the method, to reduce the influence of accident uncertainty, the accident risk is used to represent the sensing tasks of traffic accidents, and sensing task representation model is constructed by estimating the intrinsic temporal-spatial distribution of accident risk according to the wavelet transform and optimal transport theory. Meanwhile, to determine the users in future, a user estimation model is established according to macro statistical characteristics of traffic flow. Then the task allocation problem is transformed into a coverage problem for accident risk. A task allocation model is constructed by minimizing the user incentive cost with coverage level constraints of accident risk. And a greedy algorithm is proposed to solve it. To validate the proposed method, sensitivity experiments, robustness experiments, and comparison experiments are carried out on an open data source. The results show that the proposed method is efficient and reliable under different traffic conditions. The proposed method provides a reference for the long-term task allocation with non-deterministic tasks and unknown users.

title: Cost-effective Parallel Cooperative Charging Scheduling for UAVs
authors: Sixu Wu, Yun Yang, Haipeng Dai, Linfeng Liu, Fu Xiao, Jia Xu
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have recently been widely used in various fields. However, both cooperative charging scheduling and insufficient charging facility problems in UAV charging scenarios have been rarely studied. This paper studies parallel cooperative charging scheduling of UAVs. We adopt cooperative charging to reduce the total cost and parallel scheduling to enable UAVs can be charged even if the number of UAVs is more than the number of charging facilities. We formulate the Parallel Cooperative Charging Scheduling for UAVs Problem (PCCSUP) for optimizing the total cost of whole charging system. We first investigate the special case of PCCSUP with single charging station, and use the approximation algorithm for Uniform Parallel Machines Scheduling Problem (UPMSP) to solve the special case. Then, a greedy approach based approximation algorithm is proposed to solve the PCCSUP, where we use the approximation algorithm for UPMSP to obtain the charging arrangements and the Set Covering Problem (SCP) optimization framework to obtain the charging groups. The results of extensive simulations demonstrate that our algorithm can reduce up to 59.81% total cost compared with the benchmark algorithms. Finally, we discuss and design the algorithms for three related problems: PCCSUP with different arrival times, PCCSUP with K-anonymity, and charging arrangements for excluded UAVs.

title: Multi-AAVs Collision-Free Flocking and Navigation in Dynamic Environments
authors: Junling Shi, Hanyu Li, Ammar Hawbani, Liang Zhao, Ammar Muthanna, Redhwan Algabri
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Multiple autonomous aerial vehicles (AAVs) system is consisting of multi-AAVs through collaborative techniques to efficiently accomplish various tasks in complex scenarios. Collision free flocking and navigation strategies for multi-AAVs in complex dynamic environments are still challenging in several aspects: real-time collision avoidance of dynamic obstacles, complexity of collaborative multi-AAV path planning, and group stagnation problem due to local optimization in dynamic environments. Traditional flocking algorithms usually rely on strict rules with limited adaptability to different environments. While Reinforcement Learning (RL), as a flexible and model-free framework, is able to solve some of the problems through autonomous exploration, it still suffers from challenges such as sample inefficiency, unstable training process, easy to fall into local optimums of the policy, and difficult to converge in sparse reward scenarios. In order to improve the training efficiency, we propose an improved algorithm called Curriculum-based Heuristic Guidance TD3 (CHTD3) for solving collision-free flocking and navigation of multiple AAVs in dynamic environments. The core idea is to decompose the task of AAV collision avoidance and navigation in dynamic environments into multiple sub-tasks and gradually increase the number of sub-tasks in a staged manner, while combining the heuristic rules with the Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic policy gradient (TD3) to solve the problem of prolonged learning cycle commonly found in the traditional RL methods. In addition, to better cope with complex and dynamic environments, we customize a risk assessment criterion and introduce a Human-AAV Collaboration (HAC) mechanism to enable the human operator to intervene at necessary moments to assist the AAV's motion decision. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the CHTD3-HAC approach in multi-AAVs collision-free flocking and navigation.
